text: Roast and light hint of oak. Comes off a little sour. Perhaps something off with the lines at Birch and Barley. Id say its good but not really a dunkel. Light tangy finish. Tap.
4 oz pour on draft at ChurchKey. Dark brownish black with beige head. Aromas of grains, slight dark fruit. Tastes of dark fruit, grains, raisins. Light body with a dry finish. Nice dunkel.

Deep garnet with a beige and voluminously foamy head which lasts well and gives the beer a lighter feeling. Aroma is caramelised toffee, with maybe a slightly nutty backdrop which almost exactly mimics the taste. A slight amount of bitterness to counteract the sweet caramel taste and a perfectly gauged mouthfeel to complement both the level of carbonation and the ABV. A very easy drinking and (relatively) low ABV beer to enjoy all night. Nothing spectacular but sometimes you just fancy a very well executed and balanced low ABV beer and at this Hot Rocks excels.

I didn't take any extra notes when I tried this beer for the first time but I'm gonna try it again and update my comments.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Le nez est ferreux, hyper caramélisé et cendré avec des signaux de fumée. Je suis complètement pris par surprise par celle-là, on croirait un decoction mash. Les minéraux sont vraiment palpable, comme boire une bière flitrée par un bloc de granite. Buvabilité volcanique sans équivoque.

Bottle, courtesy of Mr Gretton. Dark red brown with a large pillowing foam. Aromas are cookie dough malts with nutty cocoa powder and light coffee. Yeasty with hints of cherry cola. Bready yeast with raisins and a woody, mineral character. Flavours are toasted dark toffee malts with earthy, nutty notes. Raisin fruitiness with dark cherries and chocolate. Nutty and roasted on the finish. Good.
Aroma is malts, toffee and mildly smoky. The flavor is malts/dark malts, mildly smoky, a mineral/metallic hint and a sweet/slightly sour finish.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2015 Sample, brown bottle, 1 pint 6 ounces, savoured in October 2014; eye: dark brown, opaque, tiny ring of brown head, no lacing; nose: malt, light acridness, light burnt, light caramel; mouth: malt, light acridness, light burnt, light caramel, finale in malt with presence of acridness, medium body, average carbonation, mildly sweet, lightly harsh texture; overall: fine
 
FRANÇAIS
 
Échantillon, bouteille brune, 1 pinte 6 onces, savourée en octobre 2014; il : brun foncé, opaque, petit anneau de mousse brun, pas de dentelle; nez : malt, légère âcreté, léger brûlé, léger fumé, léger caramel; bouche : malt, légère âcreté, léger brûlé, léger fumé, léger caramel, finale en malt avec légère présence dâcreté, corps moyen, carbonatation moyenne, moyennement sucrée, texture légèrement râpeuse; en résumé : bien

Bomber into a glass. Pours a deep and dirty mud brown mixture with no clarity. Huge frothy medium white brown head, extensive lacing, retains well. Aroma of coffee, cherry, brown malts, a relaxed vibe to the nose, some choco, and velvet frosting, a small booze kick mixed in. Taste of a solid brown lager, just fluid with an easy going lager kick, grass, some soft citrus tones, carbonation is perfect and adds to the relaxed vibe. Abv settles in accordingly, I wish this was more readily available, like in six packs, a nice beer here, perfect lager.
Old rating. Cool beer. Light brown color. Sweet, smoky, with almost chocolate and coffee tones. Mild bitterness and medium bodied. Good balance and drinkable.
Pours deep brown with red tint. Quickly disappearing head. Slight smokey sweet taste. As well as Carmel notes

Bottle, also taster at LA/PB. Aroma is smoky plus dark malts. Obviously not your average lager. Taste could fairly be described as stout x lager -- you get the choco and coffee notes up front with a clean finish. If "stout lager" sounds good to you, drink this. Sorry to be so basic.

DWF; Bottle at Cardinal. Pours dark brown with moderate lasting, bobble, frothy, lacing tan head. Nose is heavy malt, bread, moderate chocolate and coffee, light grass and citrus. Taste is moderate sweet, spicy and light bitter with a moderate finish. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is flat.

On tap at the brewery. Dark brown pour with a light brown head. Enticing malt aromas. Lots roasted malts, but not bitter or overly roasted, with caramel and chocolate undertones. Great body and mouthfeel. A fantastic Dunkel. Coffee.

Bomber from Binnys in Bloomingdale, IL. Dark cola pour that looks a bit dense, and a nice frothy head. Good looking beer. Aroma is a bit of raisin and tea. Fuller palate, slight bitterness. This is pretty darn good.
Thanks to rejtable for this. Pours a dark reddish brown with a small white top. Aroma is slight caramel and earthy hops. Taste is a very well balanced lager.

This was nice. Pours clear brown with no head or lacing. Nose is caramel with some breakfast tea. Flavours are caramel, syrup, bitter tea. Medium bitterness and light/medium sweet. Full body with light carbonation.

Bottle. Pours darker amber in color with a slightly tanned head. Bit of roasted notes and nuttyness in aroma, some sweeter notes of toffee and biscuit too is there. Actually one could get some notes of campfire as well, that would probably be the steinbier contribution here. Notes of openfire breadyness, sweet toffee and dark fruits in taste. More towards the bitter side in the end with some notes of dark chocolate and coffee.

22 oz bottle poured into glass...Pours dark and golden, but dirty, with a beige, dirty head. The aroma is malty but pleasant. The flavor is coffee-like, with hints of nuttiness & chocolate, bitter, but not too bitter. Overall, it was a nice beer that I could drink daily
Bottle from SJ trade. Nice notes of sweet malt, spice and caramel. The finish was spice , but not over bearing. I liked it a lot.

Pours three fingers of tan head on a dark brown-red colored body.
The aroma has roasted malt and a little cocoa power. Nice.
The taste is dark roasted malt, bitter chocolate and a little cream.
The texture is soft and fizzy.
Excellent flavors and smell.
Pours dark black with white head. Strong but simple raisin flavor with a strange viscous mouthfeel. Did like it but not the best I had all night.
Drank from pint glass poured from a large bottle. Delicious. Nice beautiful black color low carbonation with a nice beige thick head. Nice malty aromas and taste. Delicious.
Draft sample at the brewery which is cool because the actual chunks of granite are outside. Dark brown pour. Light aroma of chocolate malt. Nice flavor of coffee and darker roasted malt. Nice.
Toffee nose backed with a light smokiness. Little head retention or lacing from a bottle pour. Nice flavors of caramel and coffee with a hint of booziness. Flavor is long lasting.
Bottle @midlaren with dutchdrebus. Brown red color with a beige head. Smells sweet, ranja, malts. Tastes brown sugar, fruity, malts.

Caoba oscuro con espuma beige densa y cremosa. Aromas de frutos rojos, toffee y tostados. Cuerpo ligero, con inicio dulce y afrutado, al que sigue un toque achocolatado que se une a un suave amargor final. Muy rica,
Draft. Dark cola with a thick tan head. Aroma is smoky and roasty. Taste adds some fruity and lactic notes. Medium mouthfeel and finish. Decent.
Bottle. Nose is caramel. Taste is caramel as well as burnt caramel and smoke. Also some of the normal lager bite.

[Tap] Very dark brown to nearly black pour. About a half inch of dense brown head. Aromas of semi-sweet chocolate, mild anise and light smoke. Taste is of rich caramel malts, caramelized sugars, cocoa powder, light smoke and licorice. Solid body. Creamy and coating mouthfeel. Good stuff.

Fairly average dark brown pour w/ a thin tan head that leaves spotty lacing. The aroma is of slightly sweet malt. The taste is primarily malty w/ a little bit of bitterness left on the palate. The body is kind of thin & Im surprised that this weighs in at 6.5% because it is easily drinkable!
Deep orange-brown pour with great foamy head. Aroma is coffee, toffee, earth, light fruit notes. Roasty coffee malt flavor with sweet bubblegum notes.

On tap. Pours a dark amber with a foamy tan head and lacing. It has a mild, amber ale-like aroma with a slightly spicy background. The flavor is dark malt and some spice up front with a solid malt backbone and a sweet finish over a medium body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Incredibly nice twist on this style, and highly recommended. At heart, its a solid dunkel. Whatever malt, etc., notes youre expecting, theyre there. But there is a degree of heat here. Almost jalapeno like. That can be hard to do -- sometimes its either imperceptible; other times it overwhelms the beer. Here, its totally in balance.
22 oz bottle shared. Pours dark. Very cola like pour with fizzy head. Semi-smokey aroma. A lot of caramel and malt flavor with a smokey, flavorful finish. Good stuff.

Bottle:Deep ruby amber coloured, presumably clear, very stable and lacy off-white head; not too sweet caramelly and roasty nose, dried red fruits detectable; moderate bitter-sweet flavour, medium to full bodied and pretty soft; drier robust bitter-sweet finish with caramel and an ashy touch. A well drinkable and pleasant brew

Keg at Port/Lost Abbey tasting room, 18/04/14.
Dark mahogany brown with a moderate light tan covering that dissipates and retains.
Nose is dark malt, light spice, candied orange peel, whiff of smoke, hint of cocoa.
Taste comprises dark toffee, earthy pangs, spice, biscuit malt.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close.
Solid offering for the style.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
Dark amber to brown in color... Aroma of light nutty malts... Flavor is sweet caramel malts, dark fruits, fruity finish... Solid lager

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

bottle. pours a deep mahogony with clarity and thick foaming head that laces the glass till the end. fresh sweet malts and hints of dark fruit in aroma. roasted malts, caramel , dark fruits and herb. smooth and balanced. easy drinking. really nice.

Draught at the brewpub in San Marcos. Dark amber/brown beer with a nice beige head. Malty caramel aroma, licorice, chocolate, grassy, fruity, roasted notes, some bitter hops. Roasted chocolate and grape flavor, licorice, cocoa, some tar, grassy hops, some vinous notes.

Pours an amber brown color with a beautiful tan head and lacing. Caramel, malt, toffee and biscuit aroma. Malt, caramel, toffee, biscuit, nut, toast and raisin flavors. Medium body and carbonation with a slightly sweet taste. Caramel and malt finish.
Semi- Clear Carmel reddish brown color. Light roasted smells. Nutty brown taste with a slight sweet comes in. Rinses clean minimal aftertaste.

On tap into a 4 oz english tulip sampler. The initial notes are dark berry with some yeast smell. A toasty toffee aroma comes through a bit late with a light citrus note. It pours a clear caramel color with a coffee brown head that leaves some lace as it goes down. Its a bit bitter and a bit sweet on the tongue - a nice balance between the two. Its a medium bodied beer with notes of roasted toffee malt, but mostlly dark chocolate and cacao. Its a bit smoky and some resin appears at the finish, but its pretty clean otherwise. The soft carbonation keeps this one smooth.

Nutty with notes of toast, caramel, and roasted malt. Reminds me a lot of a nut brown ale, with the crispness of a lager. Not sure what the effect of the hot rocks was, but who cares, its a good beer.

$5.30 for the 650 mL bottle purchased from Learys. To long-stemmed wine glass, it pours a rusty-red, brownish crimson with a sudsy, off-yellow-white head 1 finger in length. Aromas of pickled pears, sawdust, melted crayons, Bible paper, bile, red wheat, and minerals. Tastes the same only with the addition of herbal and medicinal hops, caramelized onions, and white wine lees. Just a clusterfuck of strange. Unmemorable.

650ml bottle. Clear, ruby red glowing darkest brown colour with average to huge, frothy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, beige head. Dark malty aroma, a touch of malt lozenge, chocolate. Taste is dry to bitter hoppy, slightly roasty dark malty; lively carbonation, dry, roasty finish.

A nice beer thin but not for abv. Sweet light caramel and toast strong carbonation. Nice head that fades. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Usual dunkel looking, with a foamy beige head over the reddish deep brown color. Earthy aroma, with a back of toffee and brown sugar. Better mouthfeel, with notes to toffee, butter and some yeast. There are a continuous spicy hint which completes and enriches the overall, giving a very original twist to the beer. Great development and spicy finish. Liked a lot.

Mid dark brown pour big tan head. Aroma of molasses, char, tang. Tastes like brown sugar, toast, milky, butter. Sharp acidity and strong carb for a darker beer keep it from being oversweet like so many other dunkels. Like a brown ale version of swartzbier.

650ml bottle. Pours out dark brown with tonnes of head. Aroma of roasted malt, campfire, twigs. Sticky toffee, nutty, malty taste. Has a unique character of its own, tasting like a nice fusion between the modern and the traditional. Good stuff.
Botella de 65 cl en el lupulo. Marzo - abril de 2013. Cuerpo ligero. De las más normales que he tomado de la marca. Está bien se podria repetir.
Bottle. Cloudy, very dark amber. Really nice, off-white head. Aroma is a malty, fruit cake smell. Taste is sweet up front and bitter after taste with hints of caramel and dried fruit.

500ml bottle. Pours a dark rusty brown with a medium lasting beige head. Aroma and taste is sweet dark caramel malt and grains, some mild dark fruit notes and yeast with light bitterness. Palate is a medium body, smooth with good carbonation. The finish is dark malted grains and caramel, some toasted malt and yeast, with mild dark fruit flavor and soft bitterness on the end for balance. A very good caramel malt character. Overall this is a well balanced, tasty and enjoyable brew any time, very good brew.

Hazy amber with a thin tan topper. Aroma of toffee, bready malt and some other stuff that accidentally disappeared from my notes. Taste is sweet with toffee, caramel plus mild fruit and finishes up mildly sticky.

Bottle gently shared by colleagues at work. Pours dark ruby amber with a tan head. Aroma of caramel malts, biscuit, brown sugar, ripe fruits (mostly plums ) and some grains. Taste has a nutty kinda feel, caramel malts, brown sugar, weak hops and some mild english liquorice.

Pours very dark, almost black with a compact foam head. Aroma is caramel, honey, rye bread, orange zest, roasted malts. Taste is caramel, roasted malts, rye bread, honey. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours dark brown to black with thick, tall tan head. Aroma of belgian yeast, earth, dark bread, spices. Taste is nut roasty sweetish with long light bitter finish. Body is medium and creamy with soft carbonation. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at GABF 2013, super malty and has some nice heat, body was smooth and creamy.
Really tasty. Hops grain dominate. Chocolate infuse nicely thoughout the beer. A lite sweetness. Dry finish.

Bottle at the 2nd tuesday tasting. Pours clear dark brown with a small off-white head. Aroma is a bit oxidized, caramel, licorice and some port notes. Taste is sweet, caramel, licorice, bot oxidized with a soft bitter finish. Medium body and carbo. Quite nice, especially considering the age of the bottle.

Bottled @ de Molen, most possibly about 5 years old, small sample. Slight hazy copper color, short head. Aroma of caramel and chocolate malts, quite some raisin and nicely aged caramel. Soft sweet, soft bitterness. Didnt expect a lot, but it turned out very nice actually. Never tried it fresh though.
Bottle @ 2nd tuesday tasting @ de molen. Aroma has raisin, port, caramel, some liquorice, interesting. Flavour is caramel, liquorice, spices. Holding up great.

Bottle at the De Molen Second Tuesday tasting, September 2013. Poured a clear dark chesnut brown with a broken off-white head. The aroma is rich red-berry fruit and nuts. The flavour is medium bitter with a super fruity, creamy palate with some liquorice and caramel sitting there too. The finish is bitter yeast with a hint of sourness. This beer contains so many flavours!

Sample at the molen monthly tasting.
Thin off white head. Clear burgundy piyr. Some caramel. Nice brew.

6.5% A stein beer, meaning it was brewed using hot rocks to heat the wort. In this case, black granite. A very dark brown pour with a dark beige head makes this a most unusual looking lager! The aroma is burning rocks, fire & a hint of malts. An interesting taste, malty sweet then burning, fire & a kind of bitter roast finish. Worth trying just to say youve had a stein beer. On its own merits it is ok though I think the style might better suit a stout...

Pours dark brown, big foamy head. Nose is caramel, pretty weak aroma. Taste is toasty, roasted malts, a little bitter coffee and dark chocolate on the back end. Not sweet. Not bad, not great. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Great lager with some unique flavors. Strong for a lager but very balanced. A little hoppy and smooth malt. Good beer.
Roast. nuts, and a little coffee and chocolate in the aroma. More of the same in a relatively mild flavor. Tasty but not overpowering, this is a fine change-of-pace but still a crowd pleaser.
22 ounce bottle. Pours dark brown with a small biege head. Aroma of roast, chocolate, and caramel. Taste is roasted malt, caramel, chocolate, fruit, and some smoke. Very nice. Very easy to drink.

22 ounce bottle from Total Wine Sacramento, extremely toasty with a crisp finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: Caramel with a barely detectible smokiness.
Appearance: reddish brown with an off white head.
Flavor: Malt with an unpleasant bitterness.
Palate: Medium bodied.
Overall: Boring and bland.

Aroma of nice crisp pine hop and burnt toast (in a good way).  Pours deep brown with good carbonation but no head.  Taste is slightly roasty but still pleasant.  Notes of crusty brick oven bread.  Easy to knock back.
Draft at Heroes and Legends in Claremont. Black color, tan edge head, solid lacing. Aroma of coffee grounds, mill chocolate. Taste is rich and roasty.  One of the tastiest tmavy beers Ive ever had.

Pours a dark brown with a white head. Chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, nutty, earthy, sweet. I found it to be interesting but not something I would try again. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Deep brown with a small beige head. Aroma is of chocolate, roasted malts, and nuts. Taste is the same. Smooth.
Bottle. The look is dark, brown in color, and has a small beige head. The smell is roast, malt, chocolate, dirt, and earth. The taste is cocoa, roast, chalky, desert, and earth.
A dark brown pour with some light brown head. Has a strong coffee aroma lacking any chocolate. Flavor is strong in wood and oak with some hints of coffee. A very smokey heavy beer.

22 ounce bottle into lager glass, bottled on 3/13/2013.  Pours lightly hazy deep reddish brown color with a 1 finger dense light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers.  Spotty foamy lacing clings down the glass, with a good amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head.  Aromas of caramel, chocolate, toast, cocoa, brown sugar, pear, apple, roasted malt, light coffee, light smoke, floral, and yeast earthiness.  Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of roasted malt notes with light-moderate yeast esters; and good strength.  Taste of caramel, chocolate, toast, brown sugar, cocoa, roasted malt, pear, apple, light smoke, light coffee, floral, and roasted earthiness.  Lingering notes of caramel, chocolate, toast, cocoa, brown sugar, light fruits, smoke, light coffee, floral, and roasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit.  Very nice balance and complexity of dark malt flavors with light yeast ester fruitiness; and a nice amount of flavor robustness with no cloying flavors after the finish.  Medium carbonation and body; with a moderately creamy, slick, and crisp mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is very well hidden with hardly any warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is an excellent "Stein beer" dark lager.  All around nice balance, complexity, and robustness of flavors; and very smooth to drink.  A very enjoyable offering.
On tap at brewery. Poured dark brown, malty, nutty, little chocolate, little caramel, little bready, little earthy hops.

Bottle, 24/05/13. Pours a dark cola with a small, off-white head. Aroma is roasted, chocolate, caramel, dark bread, light coffee and liquorice. Taste is roasted, somewhat herbal and dark breadiness, some salty liquorice and ethanol on the finish. Semi-dry, herbal hoppiness. Quite light, quite a bit of carbonation. Surprisingly light all around. Would expect more from the brewery and with this ABV.

On tap at Tustin Brewing.  Woody, smoky aromas from a dark brown body with a tan head.   That light smokiness and dry, lightly charred wood follow in the flavor along with a nice milk and semi-sweet chocolate taste and brown sugar.   Finishes with a little sweetness and chocolate.   Looks heavy but its quite light and very drinkable and tasty.

Poured from draft at sheffields. Dark brown pour with a ton of fluffy off white head. Grain and malt aroma.  Odd that it tastes like a light lager in a dark body pleasant. Chocolate notes with a malty aftertaste. Like it.

Type: Draft 
Glass: 16-oz. pint glass  
From: Polite Provisions in University Heights (San Diego), Calif. 
Price: $6  
Purchased: May 8, 2013
Consumed: May 8, 2013
Misc.: N/A

Poured a brownish black color with two fingers of khaki tan frothy head. Lots of sporadic khaki lacing on the sides. Good retention all the way down.

Smelled roasty malts up front. Also chocolate, caramel, toffee and nuts. Reminded me a bit of a Newcastle. 

Tasted similar to the nose with roasty malts and nutty malts coming through the most. Also caramel, toffee and chocolate with some bitterness on the tongue after. 

Medium body. Creamy-to-sticky texture. Average carbonation. Bitter finish. 

I probably gave this beer a bit better rating than I should have. It definitely had its moments.

Tap at Angels Trumpet.  What an odd beer?  Just read description about rocks not sure what that contributes.  Pours dark brown/reddish.  Nose of sweet candy licorice.  Tastes of dark earthy flavors, nuts, caramel, brown sugar, biscuity, grainy, and some dark fruits perhaps.  light lager mouthfeel.
(Bottle 17/04-2013) Medium beige head, dark amber red color, sweet caramel aroma, slightly odd taste.

Theres a common taste in most of Port Brewing beers. I want to say its a combination of nutty and creamy. Subtle, but reoccurring. This one had a bit more kick than I expected. The color threw me off for sure. Vanilla Nutty cream with a zingy aftertaste.  Great beer!

Pour is dark brown with a small tan foamy head that fades after a few minutes. Aroma is light and dry with notes of caramel, simple sugars, some spice. Very little hop presence. Flavor is more balanced, but still leaning towards the sweet side. Subtle touches of dry smoke in the finish. Interesting.

Pours brown with a small tan head. The nose is caramel, granite, BBQ and cherry. The taste is well balanced medium bitter and sweet. The texture is crisp and clean, body is light and finish is medium. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle @ DØE meeting. Pours slightly hazy dark amber with a offwhite head. Aroma of malt, caramel, light dark friuit notes, grassy hops. Flavor is malt, dark caramel, dark fruit, licorice, little hops. Medium body, soft carbonation, light bitter finish. 170413

Bit hazy deep reddish brown with quite huge beige head, that collapse quite fast, Bit lacing.
Aroma.. malty, caramel, bit dark fruits, decent hops. bit licorice.
Sweet with moderate bitter finish.
Interesting and enjoyable beer, but nothing outstanding

Dark brown pour with an off-white head. A mild roasted malt aroma along with sweet toast, bread, and toffee. Floral hops, earth, and a hint of dark fruit. A bit of a mineral quality to the flavor and mouthfeel. Sweet toasted bread and dark fruits. Mild roast, some floral hops, and a touch of earthiness.

22 oz bottle pours a hazy dark brown with fluffy beige head and good lacing. Smells of caramel and smoke.  Aroma is similar, but also with lots of roasted malts, toasted bread, cereal grains, and molasses.  This one is malt-forward, and doesnt seem like a lager at all.  Taste is sweet with a nutty, slightly dry finish. Body is medium with average carbonation and slightly sticky mouthfeel.  Whatever you decide to call this, Its a goodun worth a try.

Cola brown with a fizzy unstable light tan head.  Nose was sweet and kinda earthy with notes of smokey caramel, toast, cereal grains, and more dark earthy sweetness.  Flavor was grainy and earthy but also nutty, smokey, and full of caramel.  Dry biscuity lager tones throughout.  Nutty and smooth, kinda complex and fun.

Bottled. Pours deep brown with a medium sized off-white to beige head. Aroma of nuts, caramel, slighly roasted malt and breaddy notes. Sweet flavor that ends up quite bitter. Medium bodied, oily texture and soft CO2. A balanced  brew. ★★★★

65 cl bottle @ home. Pours brown with a large off-white head that leaves quite a bit of lacing. Aroma is sweet with notes of caramel and fruit. Flavour is caramel and roasted malt, a little smoke even, leading to a slightly bitter finish.

This was rating #4000 for me, according to RateBeer.  Bomber, Im starting off a bit cold.  Nose heavy of caramel and light chocolate, brown sugar and earth, light nuts, sweet with light bread crusts.  Pours a near-opaque dark brown with a frothy tan head.  Taste lightly sweet with firm light bitterness, some earth and a lot of dark caramel and toffee, wisps of mocha and faint fruit, toast and faint chocolate, bread crusts from Mr Maillard himself and a squinch of butterscotch.  Full body is crisp, alcohol well-integrated.  Flavorful and without any serious flaws.

Pour is a dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma is some heavy dark malt with a nice chocolate.  Flavor is a nice roasted malt with a big chocolate lingering in the back round.  Finish has more chocolate notes with some almost a rye-like spiceyness.  This was a nice dunkle.  A real showcase of the malts.

Pours brown/black with  medium tan head Nose is faintly smoky, roasted + chocolately malts. Roasted malts and dryish hops behind. Body is light to medium, good mouthfeel with a semisweet finish.

Easy drinking and interesting.
Bottle. Pours black with tan head. Good lacing. Nose/taste of black licorice, liquid smoke, steamed malt, toasted chocolate malt and caramel toffee. Medium body.

Bottle 65 cl. Clear reddish brown with a small cappucino-colored head. Delicious toasted caramel-malty nose with notes of licorice. Taste is toasted almost burned bready malts with light coffee notes and sweet licorice accents.  Some berry-like notes as well. Medium body. Lightly bitter finish.
On tap at capitol beer. Color is dark amber. Taste is similar to tea. Some nuttyness.

Pours very dark red with an offwhite foam head.
It smells malt and strawberries.
Mouth is rich and smoothie. Aromas of red fruits, ZAN (liquorice) and toffee in aftertaste.
Drinkability is high: low in alcohol, not too much foam, crispy enough to refresh.
Sublime I love it!

Darkest lager I have ever seen.  A little bready on the nose and comes through with a silky soft malt on the palate.  For a "lager" you can see why this rates so well (ie I does not remind me of a lager)

Bottle. pours dark brown with a huge beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel, roasted grains, nuts and red berries. Flavor is sweet and malty with some hay, roasted grains, chocolate and fruitiness. Medium body, averagea carbonation.

Bottle 650ml @ Geokkjer
Pours reddish dark brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, chocolate, caramel, grass and floral hops. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.
Had this one a little while ago but remember it being quite dark amber in colour with some nice caramel notes. A fairly full palate too. Good beer.

Red amber with thick rocky foamy tan head; foamy mouthfeel but medium bodied and crisp; slight peat and smoke in aroma; decent malty/roasty flava with hint of some berriies; finishes long an dry with some malt and hops.
Dark coca-cola pour with a thin tan head. Aroma of molasses and toasted malt and maple syrup. Flavor is dry and roast.  A bit of smoke and berries. Really light and drinkable.

Location/Date:Bottle on October 27th, 2012.
Appearance: Pours dark brown nearly black, with light white head. 
Aroma: Aroma of nut, caramel malt
Taste: Faint bitterness, nuttiness, light chocolate, roast.
Palate:Light body, medium lingering aftertaste, faint fizz.
Summary: The story of how this beer was made is pretty interesting.  An enjoyable dunkel that is just a hair under very good.
Pours a nice dark brown with tan foamy head. It has a nice dry roasty caramel taste.

Bottle shared by my good friend Tony, thanks man. Dark brown color with a good bit of head. Aroma is mostly hoppy mixed with dark malts and perhaps even a tad of spice to it. A very interesting and different beer.

Bottle as shown. Pours a cloudy brown with medium frothy off white head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is caramel malt and toast with fruit. Medium mouthfeel with a sweet malt and chocolate with light bitter finish. A good dunkel from Port Brewing.
Pours darker than I expected. Nice beige head, with good lacing. Smoke, chocolate, and caramel flavors. Reminds me more of a porter than a lager. Very good. Highly recommended.

Bottle from Kihoskh. Clear dark brown with a big and lasting beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, heavy caramel and some roasted malt. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter. Full bodied. 290912

Bomber from Whole Foods Market Paramus. Pours a clear dark brown color with a large frothy brown head. Good head retention. Aroma of caramel, earthy notes, herbal notes, stone fruits and a faint bit of smoke. The taste is caramel, toasted notes, faint burnt notes, faint smoke, herbal hops. Medium bodied. Very nice beer.

22 ounce bottle. Transluscent dark red, brown color. Large rocky beige head. Rich burnt caramel malt nose hints at roasted root vegetables and soy sauce. Roasted caramel malt flavor, more soy sauce. Rich and chewy with a hint of worcestershire sauce, chocolate, pumpernickel bread, currants and coffee beans. This brew improves as it warms and develops complexity as you slowly sip it.

Bottle courtesy of Marsiblursi. Pours hazy dark slightly reddish brown with a frothy goldenish brownish white head that slowly dissipates while leaving some thick lacing on the glass. Smell is sweet and malty with caramel, sweet dark bread, dates, sweetened coffee, fresh grass, peppery wood, apricots, burnt sugar, fruit toffee, roasted almonds and hints of oat flakes. Taste is slightly sweet, slightly bitter and malty with pumpernickel, plums, burnt sugar, dates, cereal, roasted nuts, sweet dark bread, fruit cake, brown sugar, straw, moist tobacco, hints of pine and very subtle hints of cabbage. Mouthfeel is round, tiny oily bitter and medium bodied. Finish is tiny sweet, slightly bitter and malty with sweet dark bread, burnt sugar, roasted nuts, pine, moist tobacco, lemon balm, dry wood and hints of toffee.

(Bottle) Pours dark nut brown with a creamy, nougat coloured head. The aroma holds dark caramel, brown sugar, caramelized honey, roasted marshmallows, dark nut bread, nutshells, coffee, powder, raisins, light prunes, vanilla and a touch of hops. The flavour is light sweet, light bitter and tiny acidic with notes of dark bread, dark caramel, nuts, touch of dark fruits, balanced hops and fancy roast. The mouthfeel is soft, round, fairly robust and tiny tart with a light carbonation. Malty and light hoppy finish. Medium bodied.

Draft at Eulogy. Very dark brown pour with a foamy tan head. Tootsie Roll. Root Beer. Dark sugar caramel. Burned marshmallows. Ash. Sweet but a nice dry finish. Nice dark malt notes but maybe a tad watery.
Bottle.Dark brown colour with head.Aroma of dried fruity,berries and chocolate,also good tosted flavor of caramel and malt.nice full body and nice well balanced full body,really nice beer.

Bottle.  Pours clear dark amber to brown with an average, frothy light tan head, medium retention with good lacing.  Aroma is toast, nutty, and caramel malt, dark fruity esters of dates and figs with earthy and woody hops.  Flavor is malt dominant with light hops and bitterness, medium fruity esters, a clean lager character and a sweet finish.  Medium body and carbonation.
65.5cl bottle at Håndverkerstuene.  Very dark colour for a lager. Small head. Aroma is very malty. Notes of caramel and syrup. Flavour is sweet with faint hints of bitterness. Malty and carbonated.

22oz bottle I picked up while in Illinois. Knowing nothing about this beer other than the name of it when I picked it up, it poured a much darker color than I expected. Dark brown color with a medium sized dark tan head. Aroma was medium roasted malts, touch of dark bitter sweet notes. Interesting brew!

Bottle: dark reddish-brown pour with large pillowy tan head.  Aroma is malty with some light roast grain, coffee and caramel. Flavor floods in with powdered malt, toffee, chocolate, a little coffee roast, some doughy bread, and a little grainy bitterness toward the end. Palate has a big malty sweetness with a dab of grain bitterness in the end. Very interesting flavors that seem to change slightly with each sip. I quite enjoyed this one.

Location: 22 oz bottle from Sparrow, 8/7/12


Aroma: The aroma has some light coffee, roast, spice, bread, fruit, and some light hops

Appearance: It pours a dark brown color with a fizzy light brown head and some light lace

Flavor: Starts off light-medium sweet with some roastiness, and it closes with a light-medium bitterness

Palate: This one is medium-full bodied, with average- to-lively carbonation, and a lightly dry finish

Overall Impression: 
This one wasnt really all that impressive, but it was still pretty good.  I had the nose slightly over the taste, but nothing really stood out about this one for me.
Very nice stout. Has full flavor dark stout. Very smooth. Definitely wortha second or third round. Very nice!

Bottle, 22oz, at Nærbø Ølfestival. It pours a dark brown body under a small, dense, beige head. Roasted aroma with some coffee and chocolate, and a solid dose of caramel. Roasted malts, chocolate, hints of coffee, and a decent bitterness, stretching out into the far end. Smooth, full-bodied and pleasantly carbonated. Certainly a nice lager beer. 111022
Draught at Lost Abbey. Nice cocoa nose, some raisins and nut. Dark brown with orange. Nice roasty , nutty flavor, cocoa. A bit thin, but a good dunkel.

Older bottle, over 1 yr. old, wasnt sure about it but wanted to rate this beer, age may have caused taste to suffer slightly.....

Decent pour, nice foam, head retention, beer is smokey, flavorful, syrupy, with a slight bitterness to it, but also a sweetness as well.  Not a bad beer, good for the style but not really that great for me, just average.

get on! come on tiger! .. . really excited about this one! have always wanted to try a stein beer .. . pours a murky brown .. light head, light-medium lacing .. . light molasses, bland caramel, and light light sweet smoke .. . pretty nice beer but just to thin .. . . Sometimes my girlfriend is so annoying,  "Do you think Im pretty?, Do I look fat?", Why doesnt she just answer me.

pours dark cloudy brown color with a large tan head. nose is typical dark German malts and hops,  roast and caramel aromas.taste is dark chocolate with some bitter sweetness to it. opens up after it warms. very pleased with this beer especially due to the fact that they brewed it with hot rocks...

Dark brown/black with orangish red.Thick foamy 3 finger head with thick lacing.
Aroma is typical lager beer smell, mineral,with some malt notes of chocolate,slight dark fruit,very slight bittersweetness,maybe a bit of herbal hops.
Smooth taste medium body,kinda slick, with some chocolate,roast,and  some semi-sweet malt.Has a refind smooth mellow pine/herbal bittering almost  a bit tart or citrus.Its almost like a porter,overall taste of this beer is really good. I would get it again soon.

Pours out almost black with a nice foamy, tan head. Aroma is of chocolate, some light caramel, dried fruit and a little bit of molasses. Taste is very complex for the light ABV. Taste is of chocolate, some charred wood, dried cherries, light caramel and some light lingering sweetness. Tasty.

22oz bottle 7/9/12 (Binnys Naperville)-42° in Mug-Pours a dark brown with a huge tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, toffee, and slight hops. Taste of the same with some smoke thrown in. This medium bodied brew is well balanced and quite easy to drink. Goes down smooth.

Pours jet black with a mocha head. Aroma is caramel and roasty. Taste follows, one of the most complex lagers I've ever had. Silky smooth, hides alcohol very well. Very nice beer.

Appearance- Cloudy ruby brown with a thick, fluffy off white head
Aroam- Burnt carmelized sugar, Roasted malt, some bread
Flavor- Carmel malt(sweet but not overly), Light smokeyness

Poured from a bomber into a pint glass. Date on bottle is April 2012. Pours a really cool dirty brown with some red. Lots of off white head and liberal lacing. Aroma of birch bark, smoke and molasses. Mouthfeel is medium to thick, much like a Schwartz beer. Taste is smokey with a tinge of alcohol, molasses, cherry candy, chalk and lemon. Overall a really nice bock. Good complexity and a lot of nice flavors. I'd drink again.

pours very dark amber with a nice off white head. very beautiful and clear. nose is cooked vegetables, bbq, char, smoke, burned sugar, a equal parts off putting and intriguing. taste is quite different slight smoke bracing snappy bitterness, very powerful but easily quaffable. This is a solid backyard pizza beer.
This a very good beer for the style. Pours dark, cola like brown. The aroma has sweet malt, a bit of roastiness and dark fruit. The flavor has the same along with some caramel. Very refreshing.

On tap at Small Bar division. Pours a very dark amber with an off white head that dissipates completely. Aroma has notes of dark grains with hints of dark fruits and backing earthiness. Flavor has a bit of dark fruit with dark grains and a hint of sweetness.
Pours murky brown amber with a caramel head. The aroma brings vaguely sweet earthy malts and light toasty notes. The flavor brings some toasty malts and a creamy body with a smooth ending.

21st December 2009Very hazy dark brown beer with a short lived biscuit coloured head. Slightly soft palate. Light touch of dark malt. Subtle smoke, well buried. Semi dry bitter hops providing bitter fruit. Finishes with a spritzy carbonated bite. Not really a lager and doesnt work for me.

Aroma is light caramel, toffee, marsh mellow.
Appearance is reddish brown with a thin head, loose carb fades quickly.
Taste is a bit more bitter and cola like than the nose yet still strangely tame.
Palate is nice and drinkable
Overall an interesting take on an interesting idea but there is lots of room to improve this.
Bottle. Dark brown, with some red, and small white head. Caramel, malts, plum, toast, pepper. Finish of decent duration, fairly wet.

bottle from brauer in boston.  dark mahogany with good beige head and lace. classic dunkel aroma, perhaps a bit more spicy than normal, and flavor with a good smokey caramelization.  sweet upfront and bitter increasing throughout.  great soapy body and dry-ish finish.  Really a great and fairly unique american take on a style. like!
Pretty tasty.  Pours cola with a sticky tan head.  Not much aroma,some slight coffee / chocolate notes.  Rather chewy in the mouth,heavymalt taste.  Finishes very easy.
UPDATED: MAR 29, 2015 At Rockwells. Cola brown color beer. Roasted and some coffee aroma and flavor. Medium malt flavor. A little bit of the banana yeast aroma. Good stuff. Serving: Tap

Pours a dark ruby red that was almost black with a tan head.The aroma was of a sweet banana fruit.The flavor was a strong banana taste.The body was full with a nasty banana aftertaste.Overall not a good beer.
Golden in color, clear with a thin head.  Big lager like aromas.  Good malt backing roasty bready flavor with some hops lingering.  Sure it has Lava in the brew this was pretty cool to try.

On tap at Gourmet Haus. Malt, wheat field and cola. Brown with red highlights an khaki head that lingers wistfully over the top. Chewy biscuit belies the lager nature. Crisp ending, although the malt is glued all over the mouth.

Big Bottle. Some more amazing artwork from Port Brewing. Pours dark maroon with zero head and barely any lacing. Initial aroma and taste is a smokey scotch barley sweetness. All the ingredients working in conjunction give this beer a wet paint scent that is overwhelming. Taste is woody with plum or some other kind of dark fruit with a pepper spice finish. More like a porter/bock hybrid if you ask me. This was a very unusual beer and a rare miss for Port Brewing in my opinion. I guess I just do not care for dunkels since this is considered one of the best out there
Draft. Pours deep brown with a beige head. Caramel and toasty malty aroma with light grainy notes. The flavor has lightly toasted grains, some caramel sweetness, and toasted bread. Good stuff.

Bottle. Aroma isnt my favorite, a little smoke but mostly wet brewery. The pour is gorgeous, dark brown with a creamy tan head and nice lacing. The flavor is full, nut brown but still lager, smokiness too. The finish is medium long and pleasant - will definitely be picking up more.

22 oz bottle.   Pours brown with a big creamy tan head.  Nutty flavor and aroma with full malt backing and caramel notes.  Medium body and some toastiness left on the tongue.  Not my favorite style, but still good.

From SkjlodBurne, Aarhus, DK.
Bottled, 020412.
Amber with white head. Aroma of malt and spices. Flavour with caramel.

Pours a dark, semi-transparent cola brown with a very thick but not too persistent light tan head. The sample I got fizzed like nobodys business, so you may want to have a towel handy. Malty aroma has a firm fruity note and just a hint of miso. Flavor has a malty core plus fruity and woody notes and just a touch of caramel. There also seems to be a dusty or dirty tone, perhaps from the rocks used to heat the wort. Smooth texture has good body and a fair amount of fizz.

Pours opaque black with a hint of red and one finger of a frothy tan head that dissipates slowly and nice lace. Aromas of roasted chocolate and caramel malts with a touch of dark fruit and earthy hops. Roasted chocolate and caramel malt flavors up front with some earthy hops and light bitterness. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, smooth mouthfeel and a roasted, dry, and lightly sweet finish.
Sample at Nærbø Ølfestival. Dark amber colour with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, roasted malt, hop. Flavour is caramel, roasted malt, hop. Medium to full body. Nice beer.

Fresh lager aroma (for lack of better description).  Brownish in color.  Sweet malty, bready, maybe a bit of caramel.  Lager still isnt my preference.

Notes:  GABF 09

Bottle conditioned 22 oz in pint glass. 
Aroma. Very malty with burnt nose. 
Appearance. Quite dark red/brown color with pale foam. What little light makes it through shows a clear beer. Decent attempt at lacing. 
Taste is very clean, almost simple malt on the front, but the finish is brûlée all the way. Unnoticeable hop. Alcohol warms the back palate and throat. Very malty for a lager, but it IS a dunkel. As it warms the alcohol is most evident character, and that's at only 6.5% ABV. 
Mouth feel is a bit over-carbonated for such a caramel malt forward beer. Reduced carbonation reveals creamy textures. 
Overall. A fun drink with the dark burnt maltiness and minimal astringency with a clean lager yeast profile.

A - Pours a dark black with a hint of red and a finger of frothy khaki colored head. The head fades down very slowly leaving behind some nice lace.

S - The aroma is a mix of roasted chocolate and caramel malts with a touch of burnt malt and some dark fruit with some earthy hops and bit of lager yeast.

T - Starts off with a mix of roasted chocolate and caramel malts with some earthy hops and light bitterness. Through the middle some more burnt malt and lager yeast flavor comes through. The finish is a mix of roasted chocolate malt, lager yeast, and earthy hops.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a roasted, dry, and lightly sweet finish.

D - Very drinkable. Feels smooth with a nice roasted dryness that balanced the hop and other flavors nicely.

Bomber poured into a pint glass. Dark copper color with a tan head. Aroma is full of caramel and dark fruits, specifically the dank odor of prunes and the sweetness of figs. Flavor is very similar, pungent dark fruits and a light toffee finish. This is a full-flavored lager that can hold my attention, but unfortunately the sweet + prune combo is a little much to deal with over the course of 22 ounces.

Poured into a shaker glass from a 22 ounce bottle with no date.

A: Clear deep garnet with a thin tan creamy head that holds retention rather well and dissipates to a rather dense coating on top.

S: Theres a very slight fruit smell up front, but mostly a mellow roasted smell with hints of caramel sweetness. Smells good.

T: Slightly bitter roasted flavor with a caramel sweetness that balances well with a slight fig flavor. Very well balanced and easy to drink.

M: Full bodied with lots of soft carbonation that gives the body a creamy mouth feel.

O: I really enjoy this beer, I like the complexity of it, the balance, and the brewing process is very interesting.
Black of color with a beige head. An aroma of sugar, molasse, candy and syrup. A flavor of sugar, candy, weak bitterness and malty.

A very unique lager. Dark color, and a fruity smell. Doesnt really taste like a lager. But good!

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2011 15/11/2011 1Pt. 6Fl. Oz. bottle @ Klaas place - BB: n/a (2011-642) Thanks to Klaas for sharing the bottle!
Clear purple brown beer, small beige head, dissipates immediately. Aroma: dried prunes, rotten bananas, some red fruit, touch of caramel, something "off". MF: lots of carbon, light body. Taste: ripe fruits, some raisins, rotten fruits, touch of mocha. Aftertaste: bitter, coffee grit, off taste. Note: Has the bottle gone bad? Maybe if they would start putting effin dates on their bottles in the States we would be able to tell.
Pretty tasty drinkable beer.  Nice caramel malty sweetness and a crisp clean lightly sweet finish make this a good dunkel but nothing to write grandma about.

Bottle thanks to kleyland.  Pours a deep amber with beige head.  Has a it of a surprising spicy nose (cinnamon) with caramel notes.  From a March 2011 bottle the minor hops are still holding up, definitely some spice (Christmas type), carmelization (perhaps hot rocks?).  Medium carbonation.  Nice lightly spice lager, great nice flavored lager, easy drinking, and rather surprising for the style.
Bomber, big rich, caramelly and sweet. Clean crisp finish. I really like the malty caramel flavors on this beer

On tap.
Brown pour with a good amount of tan head.  Aromas of caramel malt, grains, hazlenut, and floral hops.  Flavor is roasted with a bit of chocoalte and more nuts.

Serving: 22 oz. bottle from Habersham Liquors. It pours a dark, slightly hazy ruby brown with a thick head of tan, dense foam.  The nose has some caramelized sugar, grain, and hops.  The flavor is smooth and robust with notes of bread, caramel, earthy and herbal hops, some alcohol, and an underlying fruitiness. Medium to rich body with higher than average carbonation leading to a dry finish.  Definitely more of an American take on the style but tasty and different.

Bottle thanks to Owen. Pours a deep reddish amber with very creamy rocky pale tan coloured head. Aromas of deep dark caramel and dark stone fruits. Really good. Flavours are relatively sweet with dryish finish. Medium mouthfeel. Wasnt expecting much but actually a pretty good beer.

Sampled @ Nærbø beerfestival. Dark amber body with a thin beige head. Aroma is strong malty, caramel and mild smoked. Flavor is sweet malt, caramel, toast, nuts and some roast in the background. Fine body and long aftertaste, some complexity. As a Dunkel this really rocks.

Sampled from bottle at Ølfestivalen, Nærbø. Pours black as Coke with a small beige head. Aroma of dark sweet caramel, bread. Taste is the same sweet dark caramel and chocolate. Lingering malty. Smooth and full bodied, very nice.

Pizza Port delivers...like always.  Didnt have a top 50 dunkel until now.  This is a pretty fantastic beer for the style (and the yeast).  Deep roasted malt with a bit of crispness from the hops and yeast before finishing with a solid stout aftertaste.  Even though advertising persuades ratings, there is def. a great charred / burnt taste to this that is quite good.  Hard to rate as this might be the best beverage fermented by my lager critters I have had, but still sits mid range in the big picture.

Bomber from Greens in Atlanta.  Dark pour with a big pillow head and tons of soapy lacing.  Aroma is earthy malts.  Tastes are roasted malts, molasses, earthy mineral vibe, wood, caramel, dark fruit, hop bitter -- everything well balanced.  Texture is medium with sharp carbonation.  Good beer.

Draught @ Oasis Micropub. Pours a medium brown with a light tan head. Sweet aroma with a bit of char. Nice toasted sweet flavor to this, Im assuming from the hot rocks caramelizing the malt. Pretty damn tasty!

22oz bottle in a shaker.  Pours brown with a thick, fluffy, light tan head.  Aroma of caramel and cereal malts with floral hops.  Flavor strong of the caramel.  Thicker than most beers of this style.  A pretty good beer.
This beer from Port Brewing, has a nice caramel and smoke flavour.  A lot of flavour for a lager. Lovely colour and mouthfeel.

Nice dark brown color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, charred wood, caramel, & some fruit; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, some smoke, caramel, hops, dark fruit, nuts, and chocolate; Finish is dry & slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Wasnt sure what to expect - but very good overall.

75cl Bottle @ home shared with DutchDrebus. I like the color: medium to dark brown with a nice dark red glow coming through. Smell and taste though: nothing! Just nothing present, this beer is -how do I translate this in English- star of anonimity sort of speak. Its not wrong, not very good. Or maybe I had a bad day. Anyway, decent beer, but not much I can tell you about it.

Port/Lost Abbey tasting room. Dark brown pour. Nice, chocolatey, bready flavor. Id dub this the "Doppelbock lite." Good hop balance, but mostly roasty sweet. Long finish for a lager, but pretty good crispness. Easy session beer but brings lots of flavor.

tap-pours brown hue with a nice sudsy lite kacki head.  nose of sweet toasted brown grains and nutty notes.  nice nutty and earthy grainy flavors with a hit of poor quality wax chocloate.  long nutty husky finish with some sweet chocolate as well.  some bitters come out long into the finish.  a very decent beer for this style-simple and effective.  I would definately have this again!

Bomber from Beer Heaven in Philly. Pours a clear reddish amber with a short light khaki head. Malty aroma with a bit of charred wood. Narrow malty flavor with some apple and caramel. Pleasing, clean mouthfeel and a very crisp finish.

Bottle from Harvards in Augusta. Pours darkish brown color with tan head. Aromas of toffee and toasted malts. Sweet toasted malt flavor with some caramel and a hint of chocolate. Meduim body with moderate carbonation.

Poured from bomber, medium dark brown with reddish hue, with nice frothy tan head.  Nose was malty, sweet, cola like.Taste was a lightly sweet, a bit thin, but also seemed to be on the dry side.  Grabbed this one at Deluxe Foods in Aptos, instead of my fave; Shark Attack Red.
tap during RBSG11 - smokey dark malts, chocolate, smooth toffee and caramel. Nice body and mouthfeel. Cool concept for a beer and tasty to boot.
Bottle from Ølbutikken. Nice head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are rich roast malt, caramel notes, nuts and hops.

Shared tasting via Facebook chat with Strykzone. Poured a very dark brown with a foamy brown head and very sticky lacing rings. Nose of roasted malts with some chocolate. Medium body and very smooth mouthfeel. Flavor is roasted malts with some hops, and exceptionally tasty.. The finish is bitter, but a very nice bitter.  Exceptional dunkel.

Received in a trade from Hayduke with whom it was shared via Facebook chat.  Very dark, almost black, but with some red.  Over half of the pint glass was tan foam that had strong retention and never left completely.  A thick layer was left on the sides of the glass.  A nice nose that is rich sweet malt often noted in brown ales.  A bit of chocolate.  The flavor begins with that cocoa and that stays consistent.  Just a hint of fruit and very soft hops are tasted.  The finish is bitter hops.  My single complaint is that the 6.5% ABV seems bigger and is too prominent in the flavor.  In the winter that would be less of a knock than on a hot July day in the Midwest US.  This is an excellent dunkel.

22oz bottle.  Bottled on 03/14/11.  Reddish muddy water color, thin tan head.  Aroma of Lager Yeast, toffee, toast, and burnt sugars.  Texture is soft and creamy, slightest fizz.  Dry flavor of fruit sugar / fructose.  Nice  burnt caramel finish.  Other ratings state that the beer has a smoke character and a residual sweetness.  I dont get any of these.  Finishes very dry with active carbonation.  Perhaps my bottle was exposed to some warmer temps, causing extra conditioning?  still a great Lager!  

6,5,4,3,16
Pours a very nice brownish colour, with some redness shining through.. Not enough redness to really like it though. The beer tastes nice but its not really special. Pretty balanced.

Deep amber color with bubbly thick head. The aroma was all malt with biscuit, toast and caremel notes. The taste started solid bitter finishing sweet. a solid example of the style and kind of cool to see such a weird old technique used.
On tap in Philly during RBSG. Pours clear brown with aromas of caramel and toasted malt. Light bodied and malty, hint of malt sweetness, faint bitterness on the finish. Solid but not outstanding.

reddish brown body as poured from bottle...small head...smoky aroma with light coffee, caramel, toffee, and burnt toast. flavor is similar and mixes the subtle smokiness with just the right amount of sweet malt.

6/13/11. 22oz bottle. Clearish red brown pour with a small tan head. Malty, caramel aroma with some metal and a hint of astringency. Sweet, malty flavor with burnt caramel, roasted coffee, and a hint of astringency. Not bad.

Bomber from BevMo Salinas shared by Enniskillen.  caramel, a hint of citrus and milk chocolate. Hazy light brown with a small beige head. Flavor is moderately sweet, caramel, and hints of background bitterness.
Very interesting concept, but it wasnt particularly outstanding. However, I tasted this a few days ago so I cant offer a better comment.

Bottle.  Pours lake water brown with thick, frothy tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, toffee, and caramel.  Taste is heavy with toffee and tons of smoke.  Thick mouthfeel.    Lots of carbonation....good beer.

Pours a pretty caramel-brown color--the color of of coffee with one creamer. Lots of off-white head and thick lacing. Savory, smoky notes on the nose with flavors of bread, burnt caramel and smoke. Long, smoky finish. Very good, very different very enjoyable.
Strong Dunkel with a unique brewing style.  Dark copper medium bodied and roasted / chocolate malts.  There had to of been a lot of elbow grease put into this brew and it shows!  Well done Dunkel!
Im not so much into American beers who try to taste like Europeans, but this "schwarzbier" was worth a try. Nice coffee and caramel aroma. A little bit frizzy, but I liked it

bomber.  Pours very dark brown, almost black, with finger of fluffy light brown head.  Aroma is very smoky, with notes of roast pork and stewed beans, with light cocoa sweetness subtly detectable.  Flavor features a malt profile with soft chocolate tones, which move on to a long, smoky finish.  Medium bodied, smooth, creamy, the right amount of carbonation.  This was pretty nice, and interesting as well.
Tap.  Dark chocolate brown color with a creamy dark beige head.  Aroma is roasty like a coffee porter.  Flavor is unexpectedly char.and.smoke.  There is a good hop balance but not much sweetness.

I really enjoyed the smokey and roasted malty quality of this brew. It also finished really dry which was surprising. A really fun and tasty brew. On draft and I got it pretty dark with a small head. Nice body and over great quality.

On tap @ FreshCraft. Dark brown appearance with a creamy brown head. Roasty, dark malty nose with a hint of smoke. Quite roasty, slight burnt, brown malty lager flavor with good carbonation and quite smooth. A touch smoky.
Bottle. Murky, deep red/brown with a thick off white head. Scent is sweet caramel with a hint of rye. Taste is bready and lightly sweet.

clear deep deep mahogany, smaller head.. clean but light aroma, light sweet toasted malts... sweet malts, some toasty flavors, brown sugar... little lively finishes very sweet sticky, medium body... Im not a big fan of dunkels when they are sweet...

First rating of a dunkel.  22 ounce bottle purchased over a year ago at Holiday Wine Cellar ($3.99).  Pours a very dark brown with dark ruby highlights and two fingers of beige foam (no carbonation problems here).  Not much from the aroma but there are some notes of creamy chocolate, dark bread, and perhaps roasted nuts.  Flavor has some nice smooth chocolate and roasted malts with lesser notes of dark fruit and creamy coffee.  Only slightly sweet.  Very smooth and nicely carbonated.  (303, 560)

Savannah, Ga - Habersham Beverage Warehouse, 22 oz bottle. Pours a dark orangey brown with a sticky khaki colored head. Sweet, but faint aroma with some ripening vegetable accents. Flavor has some faint dates and raisins, some brief hints of chocolate and a little bit of caramel. Mouthfeel is thick enough. Nice to see this brewer on the east coast.

Shared bottle at Cardinal 27.10.2010. Clear amber with a creamy light brown head. Caramel is the most prominent aroma. Roasted, hoppy bitter, alcoholic, caramel, dark fruits, wooden barnyard aroma. Medium to full body. Dry roasted finish.

Deep brown blackish pour creamy light beige head decent lacing ... aroma of caramel and roasted malts .... tasted is of roasted and caramel malts light sweet molasses and light bitter hops .... a dry bitter hop finish ... not a bad dunkel lager
Pours a dark brown with a large tan head. Aroma of roasted malts with some caramel, nuts and toast. Flavor of caramel, toasted malts, nuts, and some chocolate.

Draft at Haymarket. Pours a reddish brown with a pale head. On the nose, a light toastiness and some distincty melanoidins. Not much in the way of hops. Clean. On taste, medium bodied with some slight sweetness and caramel. Toasty notes come through again as do dark bready notes. Some cocoa comes across in the finish, which is quite dry. Okay.

Poured a dark red brownish with a frothy thick white head.  Some lace.  Aroma was rich earthy malts, decent roast presence and a touch of light cocoa.  Flavors were just as earthy, rich lightly roasted malts throughout, slight sweet finish with a smooth super light bitterness.  Mouthfeel was medium, carbonation about average, full.  A good robust lager that may be a bit too sweet to drink a lot of, but somewhat refreshing...

Bottle. Creamy off-white good mostly lasting head. Amber colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Some caramel notes. Moderate bitter nice caramellic flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Oily palate. nice.

bomber.  pours a brown color with ruby highlights and a huge 3+ finger off white head - which settles down to a nice 1/4" throughout.  caramel, nuts, bread and roasted malts across the nose.  medium soft creamy body filled with grains, cereal notes, caramel malts, light apple, bread, light chocolate and toffee.  sweet finish with more caramel / toffee and light fruits.  light bitterness throughout.

22oz bottled March 14, 2011.  
Pours copper/brown with a large fluffy light beige head that leaves some lacing and holds a nice cap. 
Aroma is caramel, toffee, toasted bread, nutty, a hint of chocolate.  Fair to good strength.
Flavor is more caramel, toffee, molasses, brown sugar, strong toast, nuts, a hint of dark fruit and chocolate, fair sweetness, minimal hop presence.  Rich and flavorful for the style.
Mouthfeel is between light and medium bodied, medium to high carbonation. 
Good stuff.  Reminds me a lot of a Brown Ale in some ways.  Very tasty and another great brew from Port who has yet to disappoint.

22oz bottle.  as a geologist...im already a bit partial to this beer.   cloudy deep bloody red/brown under a large head.  nose is really special....toasted malts, burnt brown sugar, soft over-ripe red fruits and some hornblende for good measure.  flavor has toasted malt, calcic plagioclase and plenty of dusty dark biotite...but is it really black granite or a basalt?  who cares...i was really just anticipating a great dunkel for a long time and found one.
Tap at brewpub.  Sweet Malty ale... Soft notes of cocoa and macadamia nuts.  A dunkel I actually like, though nothing crazy or aggressive.  Super sessionable.

Yellow-beige, medium head, dissipating over deep-brown beer. Caramelly, soft-roasted nose, rather sweet; light plywood aroma, more bitterish than the first impression. Mild-sweet flavour, milkchocolate and liquorice, centwafers. Finish has some black cardamome, but mildly so. Feels quite carbonated, rather light body, slight slicknes. Aftertaste is not unlike cola - or I ought to specify Pepsi, as warming up, it acquires a peppery flavour I associate with that drink from my very early days. Strange, cant get the height of this one - not even if I like it or not really.
Bottle. Dark brown with medium creamy tan head. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, bitter and sweet.
22oz bottle. Pours brown/red minimal head. Malt aroma, malt taste, not bad, not remarkable, would be nice on tape or in a sixer but at boutique beer prices not worth it.

First this is in no way a Dunkel.
_________________________________________ to jdubfl for the extra.

Pours into my large dimpled mug a decently dark brown with orangeish hues on the edges. The head is large and off-white. 

The smell is medicinally hoppy with some nice malt character. 

The mouthfeel is noticeably watery, which is a downer. The beer tastes alright though, not much like a Euro Dark lager though. It is almost like a porter meets bock. The chocolate malt is pretty evident as is the caramel.

It is ok, not true to style at all but not bad.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-24-2010 01:58:02

from erzbierschof.ch - very dark ruby-brown colour, hazy and with a poor head retention; a biscuity maltiness, decently smokey and with notes of licorice; medium to full malt backbone, a solid sweetness and carbonation; bitter and hoppy finish with long malty, smokey and chocolatey notes; slightly oily

Sample@Håndverkerstuene, Oslo, by courtesy of larsga. A dense layer of beige bubbles upon a clear dark brownish-amber body.  Light caramelly malt aroma with sourish berry notes. Hints of mild spices, pepper and bread crust. Fairly sweet, medium malt body. Grainy, toasted and sourish bready, with notes of  dark fruits. Sparesly hopped. Rounded mouthfeel. A light fruity acidity and some burnt notes in the ending.  Difficult to pin-point the aromas and flavors in this one. A very unusual beer, yet well-crafted and tasty. Nice!

Small beige head. Deep dark red body. Sugary earthy caramelly aroma with wild berry notes. Dry-sweet-acidic mealy caramelly wild berry taste with earthy chocolatey notes. Mild mouthfeel. MId-bodied. Dryish burnt mineraly sooty aftertaste with earthy grainy caramel and straw notes. Long lingering burnt earthy straw aftertaste. Lovely, and really unusual. (0.65l bottle, Håndverkerstuene, Oslo.)
bread, toast, dark brown, brown foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, salty, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish,
Dark brown. Has an off-white head, medium duration. Malty, toasted, roasted aroma, sweet too, faint hoppy. Faint port-wine too. Sweet flavor, moderate bitter finish.
$20 bottle at Fallen Rock club, Denver. Shared with JMSHB.  Darkish body, almost nohead though lace.  Sweet with spice, root beerish.  A brown ale more than anything. Average mouthfeel.

Bottle. Poured dark brown color with an average frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Medium malty aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium dark bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of average duration. This beer met my expectations.
A little rye in the aroma. Dark brown and very very cloudy. This has a home-brew Englishness to the beer. Quite tasty stuff.
65cl, new American brew Anno 2009, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex brew, yet easy to drink, balanced, hazy, good head, nice brew, yet expensive!
Brown pour. Caramelly and malty nose. taste is similar and sweet but not cloying. Good.
Bottled. Very authentic probably. Too much raisin and vegetation in both nose and taste for me. Sharp, slightly metallic. Subdued bitterness. Not at all my kind of beer.

Bomber pours cloudy cola amber with thick frothy tan head. Aroma is caramel, bread, and dark fruits. Taste has an earthy toasted flavor, nuts, caramel, roasted malts, nice bitterness all the way through. Really nice loving the roasted and toasted characters.

200th rating!!

1 pt. 6 fl. oz. bottle, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 6.5%. Very dark brown colour, big to moderate beige head. Moderate aroma of caramel and toasted brown bread, hints of dark dried fruits.  Decent flavour, caramel and toasted brown bread again, a hint of fruit, moderate but sufficient hops in the finish. Well balanced and pleasant to drink.
Bottle. Unfiltered dark brown. Lasting froth. Aroma of biscuit, chocolate and hops. Chocolatey hops and cookie flavour. Nice hoppy airy aftertaste. Chocolate hop aura keeps the tongue awake.

The label says this is a collaboration with Bend Brewing, but it is under just the Port imprint. I like the hot rocks technique.  I read that Dogfish Head was doing something like it - this may be an old Scandinavian thing.  They are the people who invented saunas after all - they like taking rocks and heating them until they are glowing red.  Very dark pour.  Lightly metallic aroma.  It is pretty sweet for the most part.  There is some light astringency and it feels good on the palate.  This tastes pretty close to a brown ale, plus a nice amount of caramel.  Good brew.
Bottle. Dark amber brown, mahogany highlights. Aroma is brown sugar, caramel, metallic undertones. Malty, sweet caramel, a little bready and nougety. Medium bodied, very tasty.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottle shared by DYCSoccer17. Deep red-brown. Rich, layered malty aroma with caramel, dark bread and some inscrutable spices. Gummy, malty flavor with some dustiness. Lightly hoppy, but noticeably creamy. Rich, nicely constructed malty finish.

Really well made. Didnt expect it to be such a dark brew based on the description but since it is a dunkel in the end makes sense. A really really good dunkel. Full of huge flavor. Great brew. Great malts.

Tasted from bottle at Lush West Town.  Pours a clear, super dark, almost purple amber color with a thick tan head that slowly dissipates to leave heavy lace.  The nose is roasted cocoa nibs through and through, with just a hint of coffee and chocolate.  The flavor is similar, with the coffee flavor and some nuttiness kicking in on the back of the palate.  The body is much lighter than the color would suggest with average carbonation and a long coffee and cocoa nib finish.

Bottle at WBF-Raleigh on 04/24/2010. Slightly hazy dark copper body with a small frothy tan head. Sweet toasty and light molasses aroma. Toasty malt flavor with some light roast. Medium body with moderate carbonation.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2014 smells bready, with kisses of chocolate, hops, coffee.  smells young, but that goes away in the flavor, which finishes with a nice dry roasted malt character.  overall, great for the style, a very sessionable ale.  pretty good overall too.
Pours a medium foggy brown, nose is nuts and bread, taste is grainy with hints of caramel and moderate bitterness.

Bottle: Pours a Dark Brown with some swirling action, with a light tan head - Smells a little earthy, nutty - a nice medium mouth feel, lightly bitter, flavors are nuttiness, earthiness, with some roasted malt, and just a touch of hop bitterness at the end. Good Brew , for sure. Still not a dunkel fan, though.

Very deep brown pour with a thin tan head.  The nose is quite toasty.  A touch of light cocoa and dark caramel malts.  A touch of light nuttiness on the back of an unusually rich toastiness.  Lightly sweet with a very clean, well-lagered aroma.  Lots of malt complexity without being overly sweet or cloying.  Burnt/toasted sugar with clean, soft maltiness on the finihs.  It does have a touch of peppery carbonic flavour on the back, but this fades through the glass.

Bottle, home. Peaches, oranges, grapefruit, a huge blend of fruits, descent citric hops, good bitterness, oily, creamy, low carbonation, murky appearance, thinning lacing-creamy, medium finish of fruits spices . Opaque dark brown colour. Interesting lager.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2010 Bomber from the Binnys in Orland Park, Illinois:  It had a very dark brown pour with a modest tan head.  The aroma was dark malt with a dollop of chocolate and a rooty earthiness.  The flavor added a touch of coffee-like roastiness.  Not very interesting to me, and I was suprized to see the rating numbers for this "Dunkel."
Black with a small head. Aroma is rich and bready with lots of chocolate and coffee. Flavor is mildly bitter and only a little sweet. Silky mouthfeel. This is a simple but rich beer, and I love it!
Draft: pours a dark amber, coffee, roasted malt aroma and flavor, dry finish.  Really one of the best lagers I have ever had.

Bottle at ChrisO "Im Trying to see the Stool" pre GBBF2010 tasting. Hazy brown colour, thin beige head.   Intereesting black lager.  Bit of toast on the flavour.  I liked it and would happily drink this again.

A medium bodied brew thats  like a sweeter black IPA without so much piney hops.  Reviewed from on tap @neighborhoodSD and from a half dozen or so bombers. (Had to share this one, it is so good.) Pours a deep cola brown with a faint ring of light tan foam and no lacing. One bottle had the sediments disturbed, resulting in a muddy appearance and a not entirely pleasant shift in flavors. Watch out for that. Let this one settle. Aroma is light rye toast and toffee. Taste favors the flash fired malts with a slight hint of charcoal, Asam tea, dried apricots, black cherries, and a mild hop bitterness. The finish is somewhat dry. A very satisfying and tasty lager.

This is an interesting beer if not for the flavor, for the process they used. Id be interested to know how much of the dark color comes from caramelization from using the red hot rocks to boil and how much comes from the malt bill itself. Regardless, it is a pretty garnet color w/ only a small head of tight white bubbles. The nose is sweetened coffee and a bit of toffee. This is sort of porter-like, I think Id classify it as a schwartzbier though it is a bit strong alcohol-wise for that so perhaps it is more of a bock beer. Flavor is again some very nice roasted grain notes combined w/ coffee and caramel sweetness and the yeast character is very clean so as not to distract from this. This beer is medium bodied, which works, but the carbonation is just a bit too prickly. It would be better, in my estimation, if it were either lighter bodied or if the carbonation was a bit finer. Still, this is a lovely beer that does have its interesting qualities aside from the process used to create it.

From the Bottle at Chris Os pre GBBF tasting, Kensal Rise 31/07/2010
Malt and hop aromas. Amber mid brown coloured hoppy and a little sweet on the palate with a hint of bitterness in a dry full malt finish.

Pours a dark amber with tan head.  Aroma of smalts, dark fruit, booze, slight hint of wood/smoke.  Similar taste, very toasted caramel malt finish.. Slight carbonation. Definitely not what I expected, enjoyable.
Pours an almost black, thin body with a lasting ring of khaki head.  Aromas of roasted grain.  Flavor is roasted grain, slightly grassy, little sweet.  Finish is lasting, grainy, and dry.

Draft sample at Bavarian Lodge. So I wont lead up to rating #2000 with some lowbrau while everyone else is off at Great Taste. Instead I got to slip off the BG tonight. This is an interesting Steinbier. It smells unexpectedly smoky in the glass. A dark ring of foam over an opaque brown body. Taste shows a bit of fruit and sourness. Then the caramel malts appear. The description at the bar says chocolate, but what I pick up is Kona coffee. How nice to find this beer on an otherwise boring weekend.
