First beer after roof came down (I was into re-rating Allagash Curieux when the roof came down...). Amber colour, small slightly off-white head. Aroma is fruits, wood, some hops and mild notes of spices. Flavour is fruits, some herbs, mild earthyness as well as some slight saltwatery notes.

Bottle @ Chrisos pre-GBBF Raise the Roof Tasting 10. Poured a dullish mid-brown with a fine and disappearing light tan head. Tea & toasty malts with subdued berry aromas. Roasty, toasty, berry fruity malts and caramel on the tongue. Clean and crisp, medium bitter finish with some brightening carbonation.

Bottle [660ml] shared with HogTownHarry & biegaman -- c/o HogTownHarry. Pours a deep amber-brown with a small diminishing frothy off-white head. Aroma: Hmmm, this kind of smells like a Nut Brown, its nutty and malty along with some cocoa and a light sweetness. Flavours also nutty and malty along with cocoa, just a hint of hops and an earthy bitter finish. Theres a hint of "metal" in the flavour that I often get from Nut Browns. Alcohols well hidden. Medium bodied. Pretty good and not what I expected from a beer labeled a Lager.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2012 Shared bomber at Lunar Brewing in Villa Park, IL. Presented a cloudy, reddish brown color, with modest off white/light tan head foam that diminished rather quickly to a ring and film, and left some spots of lacing. The aroma was sweet dark fruit and raisins, with some woody hints. The flavor was a lighter version of the nose, with some low hop bitterness. A little style confused on this one, but a tasty brew nonetheless. Again at Lunar Brewing Co., but this time on tap. Showed a ruby highlighted, darkest brown color, with a moussy tan head, and ribbony cling to the lacing. The nose was some roastiness, a little yeasty funk, and some creaminess. The flavor was roasty, moderately bitter, medium to full bodied, well carbonated, and particularly dry on the finish. Quite different from the first bottle encounter.+.3
Bottle at Chris Os Raise the roof tasting. Muddy brown pour with a beige head. Very fruity aromas, blackberries and other forest fruits dominate. Fruit laden taste. Interesting.
Bottle at chrisos pre-GBBF Raise the Roof Shindig 10. Dark brown with a small off white head. Sweet honey malt aroma. Slightly plastic malty taste. Mid bitter.

Bottle at home from Kris Wines, London.  A hazy dark brown pour. with a mid sized off white headthat decided to linger for a few pieces of  lamb shaslik by the bbq......Aroma was sweet malts aplenty  with brown sugar and a chunk of dark fruit lurking. First impressions of the flavour was  sweetness up front with notes of chocolate, and more dark fruits.  Caramelt malts spot on.  All very drinkable for sure.  Not my favourite style or beer out of this excellent stable, but worth investigation as this certainly doesnt lack good qualities.

22oz Bottle shared with blankboy and biegaman.  Deep hazy ruby-black with an average lasting fizzy straw-coloured head (4-).  Smells like an earthy, dry nut-brown ale - plenty of herbal hoppiness and almost burnt roast nutty malt - maybe a hint of metal.  Taste follows - I get some peat and increasing dry herbal bitterness, but it does fade out a little before it hits its peak - nutty, doesnt taste like 6.5% either.  Average body, slick mouthfeel, mild carbonation - decently balanced, but quick-finishing.  Would like more flavour, but a nice charred nutty character.

The Dan Journal #372.  Tasted 7/12/10.  22oz bomber.  Filtered and very lively with a dark ruby red hue.  Lacing bone white head.  Aromas of faint graham crackers and dark berry undertones.  Rather full bodied and rich.  Mild alcohol and a good body.  Thick and mildly viscous.  Bright effervescence and a tart bitter finish.  Touch cocoa adds a sweetness.  Tart, tangy, sweet and nice.  Good complexity and rather tasty!  I like it!

Alright, so Port Brewing Hot Rocks Lager is another beer from the Port Brewing Co. and its another really good beer. Its not as flavorful as the Midnight Sess but its got a unique flavor. Its got a really subtle roasted flavor from the hot rocks that was use to boil the brew. Under the roasted flavor is the hint of sweetness and its all laced in a smooth finish. Its very easy to drink, even easier than Midnight Sess. It seems more watery than what you would expect from an American Lager but that doesnt take away from the experience. This is a good beer to start off with if youre new to the specialty and craft beer thing, so give this a sip.

tap at clark street alehouse.  pours a dark brown with a small tan head.  aroma of tootsie rolls, sweet vanilla, caramel, and doughy candy.  light chocolately herb flavor.  decent, but not my cup of tea.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2010 Pours clear and dark brown with a thin ring of a head. Aroma is lightly roasted, molasses, and chocolate. Flavor is just a bit sweet with some chocolate notes. Good, dry finish. Not typically my style but Im liking this.

22 oz bottle. 
Pours a deep amber, almost brown, with a thin strip of beige lacing. 
Smells sweet but not much else on the nose. Medium bodied and lightly carbonated. Taste is wondrous: the beer makes its money here. Sweet and malty with strong molasses and dark fruit taste at the beginning with a surprising cocoa finish.

Pours a murky brown color with almost no head. Aroma of chocolate and smoked malt. Flavor of chocolate and smoked malt. The body is light to medium with an oily texture and soft carbonation. Interesting.

aroma is soft chocolate with spicier backbone, black pepper perhaps. a touch of herbal/floral hops as well. appearance is opaque with mushy brown edges, well retained head but little legs.  flavor is soft cocoa with sizzling end to check palate without being overwhelming.  perfect balance.

Bomber shared by the legendary footbalm himself, thank man 
Appearance: Pours dark amber with a small off-white head and some lacing 
Aroma: Dark malts, caramel 
Taste: Caramel, toasted and sweet malts 
Decent

Bomber thanks to Eric at another great tasting. Pours a dark brown color with a small white head. The aroma is smooth rich caramel and toasted malts. A similar flavor; sweet caramel, heavily toasted malts,smooth and flavorful.

Dark brow pour with a nice frothy beige head. The aroma is roasted malts and hints of tropical and dark fruits- pineapple and raisin most notably. The flavor is predominantly roasted chocolate malt with caramel and molasses coming through as well. the palate is medium bodied with a supple, easy going texture and a dry, roasty finish.
Bottle from Mitra van Bergen. Dark brown with medium head. Sweet nose of dark fruits. Taste of caramel and malts. Sweety, syrupy. Nice texture.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, sweetness, fruit, caramel and some alcohol. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is sweetness, caramel and alcoholwarmth. Overall a good beer.

22oz bottle.  Very cool idea here.  Pours an unclear chalky tootsie roll color with a small thin fizzy tan head.  Aroma is similar to a porter or strong brown ale, lots of coffee, and sweet roast, some chocolate, clean and beautiful.  Flavor follows, straight forward with just enough depth to keep it interesting, very similar to a strong brown ale, coffee, roast and tootsie roll chocolate, not grassy though like a German beer and doesnt seem to be totally dominated by munich malt, hides alcohol exceptionally, quick finish and aftertaste. Does have a bit of a rye bread taste and rich maltiness as it warms that might limit its prolonged drinkability.  Medium bodied, fizzy carbonation, smooth with only a slight stickiness that emerges after half way though the bottle or so.  Nice beer.

Ive been waiting to try this one since it came out but for some reason this one never made it out to Chicago last year.  Really didnt want to have to trade for it, so Im glad it showed up.  Murky deep reddish brown pour with an off white head that rims the glass.  Aroma is nice: dark, dried fruits, some plums, some raisins, and then a bit of caramel and toffee malt.  Flavor is good.  Chocolate, dark fruit, caramel.  A bit of herbal, earthy bitterness.  Nice, medium bodied, good mouthfeel.  The right amount of carbonation.  Pretty good beer here.  Actually, really good.

Dark brown with good, creamy, tan head / Soft nose of sour malt and cocoa / Light to medium body, somewhat chewy, malty with mild hop balance, and good finish / Flavors of cocoa, brown sugar, toast, and lemon / Very nice.
UPDATED: FEB 16, 2011 Draft at monks. Pours a hazy red body. Aroma is burnt nachos, and malt. Mouthfeel is medium with notes of roast, burning, toasted bread.

Hazy amber brown liquid with a nice head and moderate lacing. Very nice doughy malt in the aroma. Some citric/earthy/spicy notes from hops and yeast linger in the background. Its a solid malty lager given character by lightly citric and floral hops and earthy yeast. Full and round. The feel holds up very well to the malt.

Bomber; pours deep dark brown with white head fading to the edges; chocolate, oats and grain; love the texture and mouthfeel as it has a thickness and richness to it; mild roast and peat with delicate chocolate, oranges and oats; pretty damn good stuff; full bodied, rich flavors and lovely going down
Tap at Lost Abbey.  Pours a hazy brownsh amber with a medium creamy off white lacing head.  Aroma of bready sweet malt, caramel, tofffee and nuts.  Flavor of sweet malts, caramel, toffee and nuts.

22 oz. bottle via trade with fidelis83- thanks again, Jeremiah!  Pours a hazy dark brown, mostly opaque but with some brighter brown highlights when held up to light.  Finger-thick tan head that leaves some soapy lacing in the glass.  The aroma is pretty weak and watered down; notes of caramel, burnt brown sugar, roasted malts, dirt.  The flavor picks things up a bit, with notes of roasted malts, caramel, toast, brown sugar, cola, and earthy hops.  Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a gritty mouthfeel.  Some syrupy cola feel to it, as well.  Good beer, but uneven.
Had this one @ Unofficial Dutch Ratebeer Meeting. Dark amber colored brew. Aroma is caramel, vanille. Flavor is sweet, smoke, butter, burned sugar.

Dark hazy brown with a ruby tint, foamy light tan head fades. Aroma of roast caramel malt, sweet fruit, funky herb, slight meatiness/smoke. Taste is roasty, biscuity, and fruity. A little too sweet but does have a mild bitterness. Medium body, lively carbonation. Better than most lagers for sure.

Sampled at WBF in Raleigh.  Brownish-orange pour.  Barely detectable aroma but some fruityness and some caramel malt sweetness manages to make its way through.  Amazing mixture of hoppiness and sweetness.  Im not a lager fan, in general, so this was a big surprise for me.  Lager fans will most likely not care for this one but I found it to be incredible.

Pours a dark almost black cola color.  Aroma of roasted almonds and coffee.  Taste of sweet caramel and fresh brewed coffee, with a slight bitter but mild aftertaste.  A beer that gives you a complex mouthful while lending itself to a good taste.  A very enjoyable dunkel that was a pleasant surprise.

Flaske: Flot brun øl med et lille skumhoved. Metallisk duft med en anelse humle. En del frugt i smagen sammen med metallen. Fint humlebid og en meget atypisk lagerøl der nærmest er en hybrid imellem en doppelbock og en pilsner.
From a 22oz bottle,red, cloudy, white foam, medium body, oily feel, roasty, rye-ish flavor.Not as good as i was hoping.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2010 22 oz bottle from BevMo Carmel Mtn. Ranch:  Murky reddish brown with a medium, fading khaki head. Aroma is caramel sweet and nutty. Flavor starts light burnt caramel with some milk chocolate, a hint of smoke and finishes with a moderate bitterness. Medium body is creamy with soft carbonation.

Bottle. Pours a nice ruby brown color with some reddish notes coming through when hold up to the light, with a beige head. Aroma is alot of caramel malts and slightly grainy, with notes of slightly roasted malts, toffee and some nuttyness. Flavor is filled with caramel malts and an almost brown ale type of nuttyness. I also get notes of smoke, chocolate, slightly roasted malts, grains and some faint hops. The body is medium, with a slightly watery mouthfeel. Overall quite nice and refreshing!
glowing brown color, sweet brown sugar aroma and flavor. Light and smooth palate. On tap at the brewery.

16 ounce sample on tap at the Davis Graduate.  Interesting, unique aroma with lots of fruity, berry-like esters present.  Plenty of caramel maltiness also comes through.  A touch of buttery, diacetyl is also there along with some metallic notes.  Nicely aromatic, and the diacetyl works well.  Mostly opaque dark amber body with a medium off-tan head and decent lacing present.  Lots of sweet, caramel malt flavors up front.  Smooth, drinkable middle with some chocolate notes.  FInishes spicy, herbal, metallic, and hoppy.  Very good.  Im impressed.

Very interesting beer. However, after half a glass, the burnt sugar sweetness ruins you flavor and palate. Has potential though.
Pours cloudy copper with a tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate and fruity notes. Flavour is roasted malt, caramel, alcohol, chocolate and fruity notes.

Delicious beer, but I thought it was a schwartzbier, not a dunkel when I had it.  Roasty sweet malt flavors dominate, with some sulfer on the nose.  Very good beer, perhaps not the cleanest lager Ive ever had.  Still loved it.
Ruby dark brown with a lasting off-white head. Aroma of malt and caramel with a touch of dried fruits. Sweet fruity and malty flavour with dark sugars. Slightly spicy finish.

Bottle at Dutch RB meeting, thanks for sharing skortila! Pours an almost clear amber color with a very thin off-white head. Fruits in the aroma with some alcohol sipping through as well. There is also a faint hint of licorice and chocolate. The flavor is sweet with some smoke, burnt sugar and roasted malt. Interesting brew.

Bottle @ Odense Tasting, April 2010. Pours dark unclear ruby brown with a creamy bubbly head and lacings. Nose and flavor is bread, caramel and hops. Chewy malty. A bit of cola and rye-bread. Smooth and full bodied. Nice

22 oz. bottle. Pours a medium off white tiny bubbled head of good duration, with attractive sheeting lacing, over a hazy dark brown body.....nose is sweet malts with brown sugar, light chocolate, light coffee, bit of dried fruit (fig, raisin)......taste is sweet with coffee, chocolate, dried fruits, leading a bit of band-aide, which is removed by a brown sugar finish.....mouth feel is medium as is carbonation. This meets most of the characteristics of a Dunkel. The only flaw is the band-aide phenolic which is rapidly hidden. Also the alcohol is high for a Dunkel. BJCP  8/3/13/5/6

Port Brewing
Hot Rocks Lager
Pours ruddy brown with a medium creamy head and minimal retention. Aroma is somewhat metallic with some malty sweetness to it. Some dark fruits (raisins?) and a hint of alcohol on the nose. Flavor is slightly sweet and slightly bitter with a malty backbone and eminently drinkable. Mouthfeel is crisp and refreshing. Good value at $5 a 22oz.
Bottle at home ... dark brown ... sweet toffee malts ... soft sweet toffee malts ...dark fruits ... little brown suger ... dark toffee ... quite nice.

(22 oz bottle from Kappys) Pours brown with a tallish somewhat lumpy biscuit head in my willibecher. Aroma is, unfortunately lots of Band-Aid initially, followed by caramel, brown sugar and chocolate. Mouthfeel fairly smooth, pretty beefy for the style, a bit pebbly. Flavor of Band-Aid, chocolate and brown sugar. This is a tasty beer with a nice malty profile except for the damn phenols.

Bomber thanks to suzygreenberg
Appearance : Brown with a small creamy head. Some lacing.

Aroma : Mineral, some raisins. Some malt. Feels "rubbery". Hints of honey with some butterscotch.

Taste : Hops, caramel, hints of honey, some malt, quite sweet. Finsih is dry and bitter. Leaves the mouth dry.

Overall : Quite interesting but not awesome. Decent pint. Thanks Ben !

Pours a really hazy brown with a medium head. The aroma has some limestone and some chocolate with some alcohol, no matter how much I sniff at this one I cant detect the smokiness I had expected. The flavor is chocolaty and mildly bitter with some smokiness showing up. Tasty!

22oz bottle. Pours a brown-amber colored body with a finger-width, creamy, tan head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is medium sweet with some floral fruits, hazelnut caramels, roasty cereal grains, and a brown malt earthiness. Flavor is similar. Some initial floral fruits quickly transition into a nutty, cocoa, caramel malt sweetness with a bit of a cereal grain feel. A clean roastiness comes out towards the end as well as some chocolate and a bit of a grassy hop. Finishes dry with a balanced maltiness and roasty, light bitterness. Aftertaste lingers for a lengthy duration after a medium body that feels watery at times, but works well. Very smooth and clean with a soft carbonation. Overall, a pretty cool beer. Not what I expected from the label, but the blend of caramel, cocoa, roast, and hops made this very enjoyable. I liked this one a lot.

On-tap at the brewery. Pours murky, red/brown with a medium sized offwhite head that leaves good lace. Smells sweet and dark, ripe fruity. Lots of red fruit, sweet and ripe. Tastes sweet and ripe red fruity, good, malty. Raisins. Medium/full body, good carbonation.
Pours brown with a tan head.  Aroma of caramel, slight smoke.  Caramel in the flavor, slight bitterness, roasted malt.  Decent beer.

Bottle sampled on 7/3/09: Pours a transparent dark mahogany with a thin wispy-lacing light tan head.  Aroma of lightly sweet toasty dark caramel and a touch of chocolate.  Starts with good fullness and some toasty caramel sweetness with a hint of smokiness and European hoppy bitterness with some lingering light smoky notes.  A unique and enjoyable re-creation of a classic style.

Bottle. Poured a brownish-dark orange color with a thin tan head. Medium bodied and delicately sweet. The nose/flavor included the likes of toffee, subdued molasses, plum, spices, and cereal grain. There was also a hint of leather, particularly in the mouth.
22oz bottle. Pours brown in color; light-tan head.  Aroma of caramel and basic maltiness; creamy, no hop character, hints of peppered smoked meat

Bottle from BOLTZ7555.  Thanks Jason!  Very dark brown pour with a nice fluffy tan head.  The aroma shows grains, biscuity malt, some grass, overall is rather boring compared to the flavor.  Flavors are roasty with a touch of cream settling on the palate.  This has far more going on than I initially thought from the aroma.  Caramel, toasted grains, a hint of chocolate.  Refreshing and warming all in one.  Pretty solid.  Im impressed.

Bottle thanks to daknole.  Pours a deep brown with a small tan head.  Aroma of sweet bready malt.  I dont really get too much from the aroma...Flavor of the same sweet grainy, bready malt with a touch of roast.   Some grainy sourness too (not too sour, just a hint of sour).  Although not very complex, certainly quite tasty and super drinkable!  My favorite dunkel thus far.
7/4/7/4/15 [3.7/5]

Bottle. Aroma of toffee, molasses, a bit of soda. Flavor surprisingly rich and malty after a somewhat lifeless aroma with roasted notes and a light pastry character. An herbal bitterness also picks up and at times comes to the fore even, battling the malty notes. Pretty good after a slow start.

22oz bottle, purchased at Healthy Spirits. Pours a deep, dark mahogany-brown color; light-tan head with large bubbles, mild retention, and patchy lacing. Quite relaxed aroma of caramel and basic maltiness; creamy, no hop character, very light smokiness. Medium body: creamy, almost oily presence on the palate, despite a fair amount of carbonation; medium acidity; kind of a muddled presentation as far as mouthfeel goes. Lots of caramel and dried fruits and very light hints of smoke (I thought this was going to be a full-fledged smoked beer, but its very light: hints of peppered smoked meat); solid maltiness, this is still reasonably light and crisp in the mouth; that oily slickness doesnt do much for me, however; I would have liked to try this earlier on, but only just tracked a bottle down; plenty of cola and hints of vanilla mid-palate. Medium finish: caramel, cola, and lasting (albeit light) malty sweetness, with a touch of toast.

Port Brewing Company--Hot Rocks Lager--Tonya Cornett Bend Brewing Company Guest Brew--2009 Release--22 oz. Bottle--6.50% ABV--25 IBUs?  (4.4 / 5.0)  Steinbock--Rich lacy espresso head.  Clear dark bronze color hazes brownish with loose sediment.  Toasted fig plum black cheery hop front.  Roasted mild sweet toffee dark fruit chocolate espresso black bread hint malty body.  Mild hop cloying malt rich satisfying smooth end.  Sampled 7/29/2009.  $5.99 Each.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a slightly roasted malty caramel aroma. Sweetish malty roasted caramel flavor with some bready hints. Has a sweetish malty caramel finish with some roasted hints in the aftertaste.

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
Pours deep brown, slightly hazy. Small, frothy/creamy beige head. Creamy in the middle, frothy along the glass. Fair duration. Light fruity nose, some caramel, raisins, soft chocolate. Medium carbonation, very nice creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is heavy nutty, hazel, walnuts, light roasted, some milky chocolate. Long, lingering bitter aftertaste. Lovely and very drinkable.

Bottle from Kris Wines, shared with MesandSim and suesbeerblog. Pours a russet brown with a thin but lasting beige head, not quite the pale golden lager I was expecting. Has a sweet and malty nose, slightly earthy. Taste is similar, grainy, nutty, toasty malts and some caramel sweetness, kinda reminded me of a Belgian dubbel in a way. Theres a smokey, mineral element which one can only assume is a result of the unique brewing process, or possibly a little peated malt added for effect? None the less, it does the job. Ends with a subtle hoppage in the finish but falls a bit thin on the palate for my liking, however, thats just me being picky. Tomme always does the business and Ive enjoyed everything, including the Spoons colabs, from Tanya Cornett so far so my hats off to the both of ya for this intriguing brew.

A Mes rate. Bottle opened in Trojka.Awesome russet brown colour with a thin but lasting beige head and lace. Good looking brew for sure. Nose of burnt sugar and really good malt. Really tasty Bohemian black lager type stuff. Lots of caramalt and hints of treacle offset by some grassy hops and faint citrus. Very well balanced and effortlessly drinkable. Something vaguely smoky about it. Id like to know if thats as a result of the unusual brewing process or if they have done it on purpose to add some weight to the name. Good fruity finish rounds it off nicely. An interesting and unusual brew. Would love to see a video of brew day. I like it.

Bomber.  Pours a nice deep amber almost brown with a long lasting tight thin off white head- some lace.  Aroma is yeasty doughy nice floral hops, caramelized toffee, nutty light charred chocolate.  Deep toasted malts, caramel slight toffee and molasses sweetness, doughy and big toasted malts, with a nutty slight chocolate finish along with light burnt notes, earth and good light hop bitterness- good clean finish.  Nice.

A dark brown beer poured into a pint glass. The first smell is of a malty sweetness that smells very inviting. The taste is different than the smell, with chocolate and roasted grains being the predominant flavor. There is not a lot of carbonation, which is okay in this beer. Overall this is a very drinkable beer that would go very well with a hamburger or a steak.
Clear mahogany with a medium beige head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, caramel and rye bread. Sweet flavour with roasted malt, caramel and chocolate. Finished sweet.

Bomber. Cloudy dark brown with small tan head. Aroma of caramel, bread, unidentified hops, light fruit and some earthy stuff. Taste is lightly bitter and finishes with stronger bitterness. Nice mix of malts and hops, both make themselves prevalent. Very drinkable, very enjoyable, lots of flavor, wont drag ya down.
Pours black/brown with almost no head/carbonation. Tastes like roast malts and some light hopping. Very drinkable and really nails the style.

dark brown, smooth yellow head.
aroma is caramelly, smooth, hoppy, soursh , flowery spicy.
flavor is spicy, caramel, faint licorice, complex, faint dark fruits. woody bitter.

22oz bomber. This has been on my Want List for awhile now. Pours a very deep muddy brown that becomes nearly opaque with the yeast sediment tossed in (bottle conditioned lager????). There is little carbonation here, practically no head and no lacing. Aroma is toast, rye, raw grains, some caramel, burnt wood, dark cherries. Taste is rich and full: lots of dark cherries, rye toast. Excellent bittering hops. Would be the biggest kick-ass session beer if it came in six-packs. But alas.

Bottle: &nbsp Burnt caramel, very dark, moderate frothy off-white head, little lacing. &nbsp Malty nose, slight biscuit, faint caramel. &nbsp Biscuity maltiness on the tongue. &nbsp Minor sweetness, a little bit of chalk on the backside. &nbsp Mealy too. &nbsp Seems fairly hefty, even a bit thick. &nbsp Finishes a little sticky. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are heavy. &nbsp Lingering cereal, malty, mild sweetness. &nbsp Fairly tasty.

Botella. Deep amber brown colour, small beige head. Aroma of roasty caramel and malt with honey and a bit of spice. Good mouthfeel. Pleasant bitter spiced caramel deep malty bit tobacco flavour. Dry deep malty caramel finish. Well balanced brew.

Bottle from WeeHeavySD and served in my ESPN Lager glass: Wow, much darker than I expected with a mahogany hue topped by a off-white creamy head and left sheets of excellent lace upon the glassware. The aroma has notes of roasted, caramel, and nutty malts along with a hint of prune, tobacco and chocolate wrapped in an earthy estery body. The taste is malty and slightly fruity with a light earthy and smoky finish. Just a kiss of noble hop bitterness and dried coffee. The mouth feel is smooth and a tad chalky and minerally. Overall a solid dunkel for sure, far more than the pale lager I was expecting. I would have drank this sooner if I would have known.

Bottle. Brown body with a creamy tan head. Lots of caramel, malt, barley, fruit and light smoke in the flavour. Chocolate, light roasted malts, light hops, fruit and light smoke in the flavour. Very nice Dunkel.

A clear brown colored beer, with a thick foamy beige head. The aroma of caramel with fruits and malts. The taste has caramel too. There are hints of chocolate with bitter with sweet and spices in the back. The aftertaste nice bittersweet.

Bottled. Arma has caramel malts, raisin, some grass. Clear, dark brown coloured beer with an off-white head. The taste is sweet, with malts, some dark fruits. has some carbonation. Thin-medium bodied. Okay.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2010 Dark Brown color with a dense creamy frothy cream colored head. Aroma has sweet caramel, cooked rice and wet leaves. Flavor has some cardboard, rice, sweet dark malts, some bittersweet cocoa and a hint of nuts and roast.

22 oz bottle from Abes. Poured a deep ruby/brown with a large frothy beige head. Aroma was far more complex then I was expecting with notes of chocolate, wood, nutts and spoiled grape jelly. The body was mediumd to slightly fuller with average carbonation and a slightly creamy finish. Flavor has notes of chocolate, old nuts, bad fruit preserves, wet bread and a hint of rotting strawberries. Interesting beer and far more complex then the pale golden lager I was anticipating.
Ruby black with thin white halo of head.  Aroma is melanoidins and raisins.  Taste is an odd combination of dry breadiness with raisins, cherries and treacle with residual minerality.  $6/22oz

Bottle 65cl.Clear medium brown color with a average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, caramel, spicy, fruoty. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090724]

Dark brown pour that holds up a tall broken tan head.
Dark caramel light molasses aroma.
Caramel dominates the flavor with some fruitiness in the distance.
Bottle in Odense - Shared with Mette & Douglas. Chocolate, ryebread, caramel, rye, roasted, grass, light body, light bitterness, light hoppy, light sweetness. OK-

Bottle pours brown-red with a minimal tan colored head.  Aroma is caramel, rye, and burnt molasses.  Carries over into the flavor as well, with additional notes of cola, red apple, and a certain nutty yeastiness. Starts sweet and finishes dry.  Nice overall balance and definately no lack of interesting characteristics.
Bottle from beverages4less.  Pours a tanish brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma of malt. yeast, and some caramel.  Decent flavor, but nothing to write home about.

Bottle.
Clear red brown coloured with a small off white head.
Sweet aroma of caramel and malts with notes of rye rbead and hops.
Sweet flavour of malts, caramel, rye bread and hops.
Hoppy finish.
Bottle, bought @ De Molen. Deep dark brown color. Malty aroma with hints of cake and some fruity notes. Malty sweet, roasty flavor with hints of pear, tropical fruit and licorice. Sticky mouthfeel.
nice malty aroma.  dark-ish golden color. sort of a medium alt.  i like it.  roasty without being coffee-ish.
Bottle. Pours dark brown, with a tan head. Aroma is malt, chocolate, and some fruit. Flavor is chocolate, malt, and some caramel. A pretty good, lower alcohol beer.

Bomber.  Poured deep chocolatey-brown with a short, dense cap of beige head.  The aroma picked up semi-sweet chocolates, coffee, and toffee accented by warm spices and a touch of overripe grapefruit.. excellent!  The flavor had coffee and molasses at the core with cocoa coming later.. bitterness was moderate and cocoa/cola-ey.. finished with the warm spices from the nose and more molasses.. tasty.  Medium-bodied and well-carbonated on the palate.. balance was solid, and it dried up nicely toward the finish.  I really dug this one!

Bruegala 2009 sampling - Pours a clear, ruby brown color with a modest off-white head that leaves a fair amount of lacing. Aroma had notes of coffee, lots of caramel, light nuttiness and toasted malt nots with a light sweet toffee not to finish. Flavor had a light fruity note - cherry and apple, with lots of sweet caramel.  The moderate carbonation produced a very smooth, light sticky and moderately heavy brew. Overall a pretty good brew with a higher amount of sugary sweetness.
Bottle. Pours deep brown with a beige head. Aroma of malts, raisins, and a hint of licorice. Body was a bit weak for my taste, but the finish was actually very nice. Interesting beer.

Bottle 65 cl. Courtesy of TheCheeseMan. Pours a clear orangey brown with an off-white head. Aroma of licorice and roasted malts. Medium body, roasted - and lightly burned - malts with lightly sweet licorice accents. Lightly bitter finish. Quite authentic. 240709

Bottle from La Bodega in Riverside.. Pours a very dark cloudy brown with a thin light brown head..Aroma is slight chocolate, roasted malts and a slight vinous note.. Flavor is slightly sweet with with mostly roasted malts. Smooth carbonation and medium body.. Good stuff, almost porter-esque.

Pours a nice chocolate brown color with no head.  Minimal carbonation.  Aroma of chocolate and roasted malts.  Smooth flavor of caramel, vanilla, chocolate and some roasted malts.  A it heavy for the style.
From a bottle poured brown with a little head.  Nice sweet malty flavor with a lingering bitter finish.
Bomber. Very dark brown in color. Sweet aroma of chocolate and roasted maltiness. Sweet roastedflavors. Seems highly carbonated. Some alcohol is present as well. Smooth and fairly easy to drink.

22oz Bottle. Thanks Andy! Pours a very hazy carameled-brown, with a really florid red punch. Rocky, cream-texture sunset-sky head. A rather plain mineral, seltzer, browned butter aroma. Flavor is rather tangy and a bit metallic. Carbonation is a bit flat. Some well developed sugar textures, some surprisingly fresh alcohol, and a lack of chewiness. This is alright, but theres a distinct metallic-twang that doesnt light my fire, so to speak. A bit wet. Interesting to try, but unexciting.

22 oz bottle courtesy of rustychiles. Epic Summer Secret Santa! Pours a dark nearly opaque brown, a bit reddish on the edges with decent offqhite head that dies to a decent film, laces ok enough. Aromas are a bit of a sweet maltiness, a touch of brown sugar and light caramel candies. Bit of toast and nuts, coupled with faint vanilla sweetness and chocolate, more on the softer side than bitter. Initial is decent bodied, toasty and smoothed out with a nice creaminess. Vanilla, chocolate, caramel, and a good nuttiness round out the base flavors, moving to a light brown sugar, touch of roast and decent bitterness on the backend. The roast and bitterness stay on the palate well, as this beer should be a bit lighter than expected, but still packs pretty good flavor for just a dunkel. The sweetness isnt cloying, as roast and toast with pretty good hoppiness come in to balance. I liked this beer for what it was, and only qualm may have been that the bitterness and roast on the finish, although enjoyable, could have been smoothed out a bit for a more sessionable experience. Cheers and thanks, rusty!

The mouthfeel and body on this really seems more like an ale on this one, and the overall flavor reminds me of a sweetish altbier - anyway - it pours hazy amber, with a frothy beige head - the aroma is doughy, nutty, toasty, with a wee bit of caramel and chocolate - full, creamy mouthfeel - a lot of chocolate and roasted nuts, toasted cereal grains, mild bitterness - the finish is of toasted, almost burnt grain - the alcohol presence in the finish suggest a beer much stronger than 6.5%, so if thats all it is, theyve done a pretty bad job of covering it up - flavorful, but a little messy and forgettable.

My Bottom Line:
Smoky dark chocolate is found within roasted and toasted cereals, leading to a levelled bitterness of roasted malts and wooden hops.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A veil of foam covers the dark mahogany.
-An intrusive vegetal character was kind of bothersome.
-This is very drinkable throughout; the mouthfeel is conducive to taking large gulps.
-I really like the flavors that come from the grain bill here.

Bottle.

Sampled at the DC Local Gathering.  Again, lost track of who brought this.  Pours a murky, muddy brown with a thin, slightly off white head.  Aroma is very pleasant, molasses, brown sugar, toasted malts.  Flavor is sweet, more brown sugar, more molasses, more toasty malts with some light, milk chocolate.  Soft, chalky finish.  Very enjoyable.  I think this was also sampled at the right time during the tasting as well.

Bouteille de 22 oz partagée lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal chez MartinT. Arôme: Odeur de caramel avec une pointe de noix et dhoublons. Apparence: La couleur est brune légèrement opaque. Saveur: Goût de caramel avec une pointe dhoublons et de de fumée. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement fumé. (Rating #2575)

This is a great brew and I highly recommend this easy to drink dark lager. Carmelized malt flavors abound. No hop presence but enough to round off the sweetness. I could drink this all the time. Ive had this on draft and in the bottle and if I lived in Cali I would keep this in my fridge. Easy to drink I just love the carmelized malt flavor from the stein process! Great job Tonya and Tomme!

DC Gathering, 22oz bottle courtesy of CaptainCougar.  Deep brown color.  Big, rich, roasty.  Some sugary smokiness, maybe a touch of amber malt in there as well.  Thick and sticky.  Medium to full bodied.  A quality beer all the way, full of flavor.
Bottle from DTM.  Well, Im surprised to see its a dunkel because its the best lager Ive tasted (from a bottle).  Excellently smooth and full.  Great on a summer night.

Bottle shared by Todd. Thanks.  Pours a deep, cloudy amber with a whispy white head. Nose is rich caramel, slightly nutty and a bit of hops.  Drinks pretty easy, kind of reminded me of a lighter arrogant bastard. A little hot in the finish, but overall pretty good.

pours a clear dark maroon with a small beige head that goes away quickly, and a little lacing.

smell is of plums, a touch of cocoa, and some malt.

taste is of prunes, some cocoa, raisins, and malt in the back, ends a tad bitter.

Pours deep brown with a thick two0finger head which leaves nice lacing on the glass.  Smells of rich sweet malts with somc chocolate being very noticeable int he nose.  The sweet malts are most noticeable giving way to some sweet fruits, a bit of caramel and some nutmeg and cinnamon.  After it warms, it turns rather boozy, almost too much so.  The finish is wariming and a bit sweet.  This is rather enjoyable, yet there really isnt anything outstanding about it.

Bottle, pours clear dark brown with a beige head. Some spiciness, but generally  seems to have a lot of  Dunkel without much Weizen character. Seems almost in Schwarzbier territory with the coffee/chocolate notes, but then theres all this caramel.
Bottle: I like thta they are doing collaboration brews, Hot Rocks is malty with some hoppy notes. Easy to drink and mellow. Food Pairing: Chinese dishes with grilled or steamed vegetables.
Bottle. Dark amber pour. Dark malt and chewy fruit flavors, ends with a slight hop finish. Nice lager. Another beer that could have been better for this price from port/lost abbey.

It said lager and I was expecting a golden hued light pilsnerish type of beer. The dark chewy malt and red fruit surprise was nice though. Very grainy aroma with a touch of plum working in the background. Flavor is all chewy malt, caramel, and roastiness. The finish is faintly hoppy and grassy. A little bit of sweetness all the way through.

Bottled. Dark amber coloured. Unclear. Light brown dense head. Chcolate, herbs and grass in the aroma. Flavour as well quite grassy and has a fruity and caramelly touch. Medium to full bodied. Sweet and fruity in the end with a nice bitter touch.

Bottled. A deep red beer with a thin orangey head. The aroma is sweet with notes of caramel and bread. The flavor is sweet with notes of bread, caramel, alcohol, bread, and malt, leading to a bitter finish.

22 fl oz bottle. Pours clear and golden deep amber/redish with a small off-white/tan head. Aroma is mild fruity hoppy. Fruity and roasted malt flavoured. Light caramelish and breadish. Smooth fruity and subdued bitter finish.

22oz bottle
pours dark brown, off white head.
aroma is malty with light hops.
taste, roasted malts, choclate, grainy mouthfeel.
Some light floral hops, caramel, med carbonation with a light bready palate.
Smooth and easy to drink, keeps a nice caramel  finish with some sweetness.

Bottle shared by Shyam at Papago.  Nose is light, clean banana with nicely roasted malt.  Color is a nice looking red brown rock color.  Flavor is like the aroma with candi sugar and mild alcohol.  Seems reasonably authentic.

Pours a murky brown with an almost purplish tinge in color. Smells of cinomin and spice. The flavor consists of some spices which are unknown to me as well as dark fruits. It has many flavors similar to a watered down quad. Also noticed some wine esc flavors.

In short: A lot of creamy brown cereals, almonds and notes of black pepper.  Nice brew that stands out in the USA market.
How: Bottle 22oz.  Sent to me as a bonus by toncatcher.  Thanks a lot Dennis
The look: Partly cloudy brown body topped by a small beige head
In long: The nose has a lot of this big brown stuff.  Unmistakably lager and this beer is not lacking is the cereals department.  Also quite spicy on the nose.  In mouth the beer is lively and the carbonation is a bit aggressive.  The first flavour that came to me was spicy roasted almonds.  Strong notes of black pepper.  If black pepper is not used in this beer than it is one of the most peppery unpeppered beer Ive had.  A lot of chewy cereals with round and smooth caramel.  Whole-wheat bread and almond cake sensation.  A little brown sugar but overall really not too sweet.  This is a rather pleasant beer in a style that is under-represented in North-America.  I just read the ratebeer description here that says that this beer is a collaboration of Tomme Arthur and Tonya Something of Something Brewing.  Good for them.

Bomber.  Pours a deep, dark, reddish black-brown.  Ive had this on tap, so Im interested to see about the bottle.  Aroma is light, of nuts, and sweet malts.  Flavor is nutty, lightly bitter, and yeasty, almost of stale bread (but not in a terrible sense).  Carbonation and slender body make this an interesting brew that was, not surprisingly, better on tap.

(DC Local Gathering, 22oz bottle, thanks CaptainCougar)  Dark brownish amber, white fizzy head.  Toasted caramel and molasses aromas rest on lighter swirls of smoked bread.  Light chocolate and caramel coffee flavor sit on a light bitter foundation on throughout.  Light to medium bodied, soft carbonation, malty finish.  Quite the session brew

Pours clear dark brown with a 3 finger creamy tan head that has great retention and leaves nice lacing for about half of the glass. Aroma is mild coffee, planty hops, wheat bread, a little caramel and just a hint of roast, doughy right bread, aroma is overall pretty weak though. Flavor is coffee, roast, bittersweet chocolate, burnt sugar, light bitter hops, planty hops, a little straw, roasted mixed nuts, fresh wheat grain and toasted white bread. Finish is planty hops, chocolate, bitter hops, white bread and a nice, crisp lager yeast fade. Palate is medium to light bodied with a very active, but not too sharp carbonation, creamy entry and neutral, but fizzy finish. Good stuff overall. Seems like they just took a stout recipe, threw in some german hops and lagered it. Its alot less sweet, more bitter and more roasty than any dunkel I can remember having. Still, if its a dunkel, its a dunkel and one of the better dunkels I have had.

22 oz bottle, via TheCheeseMan.  Pours a clear dark brown body with a fizzy light brown head that had excellent retention for a Lager.  The nose is slightly sweet toasted and husky malts with lighter hints of nuttiness and coffee.  The flavor is very clean with toasty and lightly roasted malt.  A little caramelized sugar and even a hint of smoke.  Finishes very crisp with a nice balancing hop bitterness that keeps it from getting too sweet.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a bit of stickiness and a good bit of fizzy effervescent carbonation.  A very nice beer, but probably stretching the bounds of a Dunkel with the hop levels.

Deep copper color with a fleeting tan head. Brown malt aroma with some celery and peppercorn. Smooth medium body.  Nice sweet caramalized brown sugar flavor with toasted multi grain bread. Basic but very tasty.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: 22 oz bomber courtesy of Sparky27. Pour is hazed (cloudy toward the bottom) ruby brown with a one inch light tan head. Falls with some lacing. Aroma of caramel malt, slight hazelnut and a nice roastiness. Also some grassy hops. Nice fresh nose. Taste is mildly caramel sweet nuttiness, followed closely by a clean roast taste and finishing with dry straw and grassy hops. Really nice transition and melding of flavors. Palate is thin to medium, though has a surprisingly full body. Actually makes this perfect for being very drinkable and full flavored.  Dry, grassy finish - crisp and clean.  Went really nicely with grilling / eating steaks. Thanks Eric, I know this wasnt my first choice, but it probably should have been!

(DC Local Gathering, 22oz bottle, thanks CaptainCougar) Small tan head atop hazy dark copper body.  Aroma is medium sweet, caramel, some chocolate, light smoke.  Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, some smoke, chocolate, light coffee.  Low carbonation, light-medium body, light stickiness.

Thanks for sharing Blake. Umber color with a modest light beige head. Earthy aromas, caramel and toasted malts gathering dust and minerals. Earthiness carries into the flavors with caramel and dark toasted malt commandeering the way. Finish has some lightly roasted malt and is quite dry. Always an interesting experiment.
Pours brown redish with nice sized tan head.  Caramel nose.  Flavor has brown sugar with caramel, touch of smoke and hint of yeast.  Very nice texture that has a great clean finish.

Bottle shared at CCB bolita release party.  Dark brownish/red color. Aroma is a bit sweet with caramel malt, brown sugar, and some fruit.  Flavor is malty sweet with some caramel and a bit of hop bitterness.

Pours clear, dark mahogany with a medium tan head, some lacing.  Smells of apple, caramel and citrus.  Medium-thin body, crisp.  Flavor similar to the aroma, with some nice, mild earthy hop notes, and a more citrus.  Well balanced and drinkable.
Bottle. Copper with light tan  head. Smooth lager with sweet caramel and brown sugar flavors. A light smoke taste with slight bittter finish.

Sampled on 5/22/2009. This dunkel pours a dark red, near eclipse red color from a 22oz bottle. Medium sized tan/beige head, with decent retention and nice lacing. The aroma is caramel, sweet, with some brown sugar. A medium bodied dunkel. The malts are caramel and a touch fruity. The hops are earthy and touch floral. Nice malt sweetness. Good carbonation. A nice dunkel with good drinkablility, there is just enough sweetness balanced by a touch of hops. The Mouthfeel is full. The finish is clean and smooth. The aftertaste is slightly sweet.

bottle: poured dark reddish brown.  Light toffe malt smell.  Flavor was smooth with toffee and carmel notes and slightly more sweet than bitter.  Crisp lager finish.  Not extremely complex. but yet a very nice brew to drink.

Thanks to todd for sharing this one. Pours a dark brown with a frothy tan head. The nose is earthy, malty, nice brady sweetness, caramel. Flavor is sweet and brady, mild hop bite and lager yeast character.
Thanks to Todd for this one!  Light hazy brown pour, tan head and spotty lace.  Malt driven aroma.  Toffee, caramel, hazelnut and light yeast
bottle from southbay.  not much like a lager.  more like a brown ale.  port does it again in making me like a style that i dont usually like.

Dark mahogany with a creamy tan head.  Straight roasted grain aroma, little toasted marshmallow.  Such a profound roast it takes on a woodsy tree bark character.  Theres a lot of body here and it takes on a creamy mouthfeel before finishing dry.  Malt, malt, and more malt.

Pours a super dark ruby brown color, only natural light revealing that it is not completely black. First whiff was very fruity and unique, after pour it settles into a standard toffee and dark red fruit spice. Coated with a light tan head and a modicum of lacing. Taste is super smooth, lightly lightly bitter and a hint of sweetness and some graininess.
This dark brown beer poured with a decent tan head and a malt aroma. There is a thick toffee flavor with a modicum of bitterness and a smoky finish.

Pours a dark thick brown color with a tan head. Aroma is sweet roasted malts. Taste is a little bit of coffee, slightly bitter, lots of malt. Not at all what I expected from a lager! Not a bad beer but a bit misleading :). its well made and I enjoyed it.

Pours dark amber w/ decent head and lacing-smells like industrial fluids-full nectar w/good residual effers- slightly sweet and caramely. I cant see past the nose. This stuff stinks bad. Long finish.

22oz bottle.  thanks to andrew for sharing... aroma of caramel malt mostly.....pours a dark plum brown with a frothy soapy white head.....   flavors of roasty burnt malt with a bitter dry finish.  drinkable but nothing out of the ordinary.
22oz bottle. pours amber with creamy biege head. nose of toasted malts and caramel. flavors are caramel and charred malts. slightly sweet malts but a dry and a bit smokey finish. nice brew.

Got a bottle of this at By The Bottle in Vancouver, WA.  Colour... garnet- brown. Nose... malty and sweet and ever so slightly burnt. Palate... burnt malt, lightly bitter back palate, and a sweet malt finish.

Small head reminiscent of cola. Froths at first, but falls fairly quickly. Body color of cola as sell. Aroma is nothing special. Nice amber malt flavors, especially in the aftertaste. Small bit of sludge in the bottom of my bottle. Perhaps a little bit bitter to my recollection of the style, but nice overall lager from the company that makes some killer ales!!

a hazy dark auburn colored body is capped by a soft light brown head. there is some spotty lacing but perhaps my glass is a bit dirty.

smells like... well, toast. toasted multi grain bread, nuts, roasty grain, molasses and something faintly fruity.

the flavor profile is quite the same... a touch  sweet on the front and mid palates but dry on the finish which is herbaceous. there is a mild bitterness and floral character throughout with an aftertaste of nutty coffee. 

the medium is refreshing and prickly while simultaneously smooth. 7/4/7/4/15/3.7

Bomber from Monument, in Concord, CA.  Pours a really dark brown with a foamy beige head. Aroma is malty and hoppy. Medium body with frothy carbonation. Flavor is more roasted malt than anything else - heading towards a porter. Not getting a lot of bitter. But its not overly sweet. More sweet than bitter. Still, it drinks damn near like a porter, or more like a dunkel. Oops. Very tasty beer. We have sweet stouts, why not call this a Baltic Porter? Why not call me f****d up? A really good beer in any case. Port Brewing "rocks"!!!!

Courtesy of Gillard. Pours brown with copper edges and tiny tan head. The aroma is sweet, roasty, a tad nutty and sugary with some yeasty notes in the background. The taste is much the same with malt roastiness, a thin layer of caramel goodness and plain old sugar sweetness with a sense of malts tucked in the back. This brew seems to end with sweetness and a sense of lagery yeastiness.

22 from SouthBay.  Poured dark brown with a small off-white head.  Aroma of roasted malt, nut, faint grain.  Taste is really malty, almost no hop to speak of.  Sweet and nutty, like the aroma with a slight bitter finish.  Mouth is smooth and the carbonation is mild.  Overall, an interesting lager brew that was - despite the style - less hoppy than I expected.  Very decent brew.

Bomber. This was much different than I anticipated. Much darker pour, closer to a dopplebock or porter in color. Alot of roasted malt on the nose. Slightly fizzy on the tongue which only lasted briefly, also a tad sweeter on the finish than the nose led me to expect. Interesting beer.

Bomber from Capones. Somehow I was surprised to see how dark a pour this was, but it was certainly quite a handsome chestnut brown with a pretty decent amount of carbonation. Strong nutty nose with sweet malts and deep brown sugar. The body is nicely full, with more depth than the average dunkel. Sweet roasts blend with sharp nut and smoke flavors, with an earthy bitterness to the finish. Pretty enjoyable.

22oz bottle picked up down in OC.   This was an interesting beer.   I went into this not really knowing what to expect from it.   Very malty overall, with a rich sweetness that makes it drink like a bigger bock beer than it is.   I would almost call it a doppelbock in the malt department, but the steinbier thing has given it a malt profile that is truly unique and intriguing.   Dark red-brown in color with a thick light beige head that leaves a lasting slick after a few minutes.   The aroma is sweet and malty with a smooth lager character, caramel, burnt sugars, licorice, and light smoke.   The flavor is squarely malt driven and sweet with caramel, some chocolate, burnt marshmallows, dried fruit, light smoke, and a light spicy hop bitterness.   Medium-full bodied with medium-low carbonation.   I liked this beer because of the cool malty flavors, but couldnt help but with it was a little drier or hoppier for balance.   By the end of the bomber the sweetness became a little too intense.
Poured amber. Sweet malt nose. Flowery and "old" smelling. Flavor is sweet malts, bread and spice. Good full body.

Bottle, courtesy someone. Light caramel reddish color, light thin lacing and nice small head. Some flowery notes in the nose, brown sugar and spicy caramel. Smooth creamy malts, grain in the finish. Balanced and yummy.

A vigorous pour into my 25cl tulip glass produces an almost three-finger thick, amber tinged, tan colored head.  The beer is a dark amber, brown color that shows a clearish, bright cherry hue when held up to the light.  The aroma has a full, malty, caramelized (very much so actually) note that is quite a bit more distinct than I was expecting.  This has an almost fruity caramel not to it that sort of reminds me of something like cotton-candy or marshmallows.  There is a backdrop of toasty, bread-crust like and biscuit leaning maltiness.

This has quite a spicy, herbal hop note to it along with a clean, biting bitterness.  The malt, while distinct, is almost secondary to the hop character; this is quite a departure from the nose.  The beer might be a bit too cold (the low to mid 40s), but when warmed it becomes more creamy in texture.  This is still quite hoppy though, but that fruity-caramel / caramelized cotton candy note becomes more noticeable in the flavor.  The beer almost has a sort of roasted character to it; it is a touch sharp, with a faint hint of roasted character, even a touch of coffee like notes, but not really roasted.  This definitely has a toasted malt edge to it that picks up lots of biscuit character in the finish.

In the end this is quite malt focused, even if I cant quite decide if the initial hop focus in the flavor was distracting or intriguing.  This is quite a tasty beer and the unique notes, presumably from the stoning process, makes this that much more interesting to try.

Bottle. Pours deep ruby brown, slight head. Aroma is mild caramel, lightly sweet, some minor spicy notes. Flavor is wonderful. Rich caramel flavors, mild touches of roastiness, some slight burnt malt flavors, not too sweet, lightly bitter earthy hops. Malt flavors have rawness and depth. Mild bitterness and roasty flavors lingering in the background. I seriously love this beer. A very complex lager, reminiscent of traditional old world central and eastern European styles. Wish there were more out there like this.

Bomber. Pours a dark, lightly hazy mahogany color. Chestnut tinted translucency shows when the beer is backlit. A medium sized, foamy, khaki colored head settles to a splotchy film with a substantial edge. A soapy wash mostly rejoins the body, just a few spots remaining behind, holding on for dear life. The nose hints at a mild infection, estery yeast and hints of band-aid mucking up a pretty nice mix of underlying chocolate malt, dark fruit, and hazelnut. Hints of earthy hops nearly get lost in the plasticy scent. Flavors show the infection as well, band-aid overtones fouling an otherwise tasty mix of dry cocoa, vanilla, dark caramel, and nuts. Medium-light in body, overly carbonated,  and too dry for the style, even the palate feels the ill effects of this brews disappointing condition. Its still drinkable, as the infe tion hasnt fully taken over, but it is still a letdown. Too bad, because this seems like it cold be a top tier dunkel.

Interesting beer. Pours with a darjkish brown color and a medium size head. Has some hops and almost smiokiness in the aromas. Flavors have some classcial German lahger grains, togther with tons of malts and some nice subtle hops. Just the right amount of carbonation and fairly smooth mouthfeel.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs and Liquor: Thought this was a very interesting method of beer making and was impressed with how well it turned out. First off, the aroma is a sweet and subtle balance of malt that relaxes the nose. The flavor is a delicious and perfectly balanced between sweet rich malt and harmonious hops thrown in. While I sip away at this dunkel I really cant think of anything negative to say other than I wish it were able to grant me a better buzz.

Deep amber, ring of head, and rather placid body. Mild musky malt and notes of sweetness waft off the glass and beckon you to recall brewing times of old. Similar to an altbier or lightly hopped amber with some added dashes of complexity. Nice base malts. Light crystal malts. Lightly metallic or "stony" quality. Perhaps some brown malts. Toastiness, roastiness, and hints of fire. Nice on the palate. Exceptionally drinkable/sessionable.

Bottle... Dark, hazy, burnt orange lager (when held up to light) with a small, creamy, off-white head. Sort of an espresso, deeply roasted aroma  much like a porter. Full-bodied with soft carbonation. Sweet, roasted flavor. Medium sweetness; moderate bitterness. Lengthy, nutty, bittersweet finish. Makes me think of an American porter.

Bottle at RnH Drink for Charity.  Thanks to everyone who brought great beer to this.  Brown with ring head and lace.  Caramel earthy grassy aroma.  Toasty Brown sugar with lingering sweetness.  No finish. Slightly watery.  No faint hint of smokiness like the classic Rauchenfelser Steinbier.  Ok.
Bottle.  Poured a dark brown with an off white head.  Smelled very strong of caramel, spice and bready.  Tasted of caramel, malt and a nice sweetness.

Bottle.  My first Steinbier.  Poured a dark brown with medium off white head.  Nose is caramel, spice, toffee, and bread.  Flavor is slightly sweet, caramel, toffee,  malt with some underlying rauch notes.  Decent carbonation, slightly bitter finish.
Deep brown with thin white head.  Aroma of sweet alcohol and light spicy floral.  Flavor is deep some rostiness and sweetness.  Interesting.

Bottle at the Drink for Charity event at Rattle & Hum.  Pours a hazy brown with a  thin white head.  Smells like a typical grainy lager, with a bit of honey on it, which I optimistically take as coming from the rocksotherwise, whats the point?  Medium bodied, malty and sweet.  Finishes with a light bitterness.
deep brownish/red with not much head.aroma is root beer,brown sugar,and chocolate.flavor is much of the same.pretty complex and yet still easy drinking.

22 oz. bottle from Plaza Liquors - Pours a brown color with a 1/2 finger thick light tan head that is short lived.  Light spotty lacing.  Aroma is caramel malt and dark esters.  Flavor is toasted malt, chocolate, and esters.  Medium bdoy.  A nice beer.
22 oz bottle.  Barely clear dark brown with a tannish head.  Nose is brown sugar, coffee and smoke.  Medium light with lively carb.  Taste is mocha and sour raisin.  Dry finish with mild bitterness.
Bottle.  My lowest Lost Abbey rating?  Pours a dark amber body with an off white lacing.  Grainy, some light plum and sweet sugars.  A bit toast y with hints of caramel.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a dark brown which appears more red when held against sunlight.  Moderate, fairly creamy, tan head that lasted through mid-glass and left a layer of foam with each sip.  Light aroma of malt.  The flavor is predominantly malt with a bit of brown sugar flavor without the sweetness.  Some light bitterness at the finish.  Enjoyable.

On tap at Lost Abbey during 3rd anniversary party.  Amber color.  I did not like this beer.  Some roastiness, but at an acceptably low level.  Leans dry. Some phenolics I didnt like so much.  Also some other off flavor I detect in many beers i dont like, but I cant put a name on it.  Sometime I call it vegetal.  It could be acetalhyde.  Im not sure.
Deep brown-red pour with a small foamy tan head.  Nice malty aroma with caramel, brown sugar and toasted nuts.  Flavor is very nice as well.  Nice light fruitiness on the finish.  A very solid lager.

22oz. bomber with thanks to BOLTZ7555 for another great bonus!  Pours a much darker than expected caramel brown with a moderate tan head.  Aroma is fresh coffee, melted caramel, toffee and light chocolate.  Flavor is toffee, caramel, lightly toasted grains, and some fresh fruit on the finish.  Drinkable, but theres a misplaced aftertaste that becomes distracting.  Thanks again Jason!

Bomber poured a clear dark reddish brown with a small disapating amber head. Aromas of carmel, cocoa, light coffee and a hint of m,olasses. Palate was medium  bodied and smooth but crisp around the edges. Flavors of carmel, light cocoa, and light fruittinerss with a crisp carmely malty finish.
(22oz bottle)  Pours a deep mahogany body with a small beige head.  Aroma of florals, caramel, toasted grain, and nuts.  Flavor of iron water, grain, hops (grass, earth), and light smoke.

22oz bottle from Perrys. Unlike any lager Ive ever had. Pours a dark rich deep brown with not a lot of head. Pretty uncarbonated for a Lager. Aroma is must and spice. Flavor is bananas, some nuts and sweetness. Finishes clean. Pretty good!

On tap at Stone. Pours a dark purple-brown with a bubbly off-white ring. Aroma of dark fruit, malt and grass. Very sharp taste, of malt, grass, pine, and a hint of burnt flavors. Lingering sharpness. Decent.

Pours a sparkling, translucent, chestnut color with an average, creamy, frothy, light tan head which is mostly lasting and leaves little lace.  Nose is nice for the style but it is faint; notes of dark bread and crust, light hazelnut, light caramelization, and faint notes of raisin and noble hops.  Flavor is similar with a mild richness of malts; more notes of dark breads and toasted crust, lightly caramelized raisins, some noble hops backing (mild spice, floral), hazelnut is still present but lighter, maybe some cocoa in there too.  Palate is nice to begin with, medium, velvety, lively, but gains a light chalkiness towards the finish.  Ends with hazelnut and light hop notes lingering, some light coffee emerging and a final note of mineral; the mineral is a little offputting but is brief.  Overall, some really nice things going on in this one with the mild malt richness, the hazelnut notes are amazing, and nice initial palate, not to mention a head that lasts for a lager.  But the light chalkiness and mineral note at the end create only a good beer, not great.  Still, very nice for a dunkel and certainly very drinkable.

From a 22oz Bottle.  Mostly transparent, mahagony brown body with a finger of small bubbled, fizzy ivory foam.  Clean, malty aromas of toasted bread and a hint of raisin fruits.  Moderate melanoidin character with some fainter caramel notes.  Medium light bodied, moderately carbonated mouthfeel with a soft, malty texture.  Flavors of bread crust and a slight raisiny sweetness up front, but it gives way to a harsh, chalky, minerally dryness mid-palate.  The hop bitterness is accentuated by an upleasant minerally harshness that interupts the malt character that seemed very inviting from the nose.  Finishes dry, with the unpleasant minerally bitterness lingering on the palate.

bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  poured dark brown/ruby with a beige head.  aroma of caramel, pear, and brown sugar.  flavor was dark roast, alcohol, and some bitterness.  medium body with low carbonation.
Bottle from jessup plaza/ Poured a nice brown color with a small head. Aroma of roasty malt and some chocolate. Taste is quite drinkable but different than anythin i have tasted, alittle yeast.

Bottle via Sparky27...THANKS ERIC!!!  Quite different than what I expected and I must say, pretty damn impressed!!!  Sparkling chestnut with a garnet hue and solid carbonation that produces a 2 inch latte head.  Caramel, cashew, roasted malt, and burnt marshmellow both in the nose and flavor.  Also has a chocolate, molasses, and biscuity quality.  Medium mouthfeel...damn fine beer!!!

Bottle: Ruby brown with a fading, yet well retained film of head. Richly malty- caramelized richness- almost toffee-ish or chocolaty. with a touch of peat and mineral character- interesting nose. Dark caramelized flavor upfront- not too sweet with more toasted character and hearty dark bread- not as chewy in texture as the aroma suggests- light cocoa, lots of minerally character and a touch of peppery mild tettanger/hallertau in the finish. Fairly dry all around and solid.

bottle.
Hazy, thick very opaque dark brown color, thin light tan head that clears quickly to a thin layer.  Thick, chewy, semi sweet malty nose- notes of caramel, toffee, toasted dark bread.  Flavor shows loads of depth- mild, light floral hop bitterness and some faint hop flavors.  Tons of malt- heavy on the bittersweet dark fruit, molasses, pumpernickel and dark bread, and some grainy yeast notes, and some faint hints of liquid smoke.  Suprisingly full flavored with loads of depth.  Palate is full and smooth, lightly carbonated, with a light finish.  Overall a superb brew.

Very dark brown pour with off-tan head.  Nose is dark malt, brown sugar, hops, dark fruit.  Medium palate in heft, but very complex, with flavors of caramel malt, figgy fruit, earthy nuts, and brown sugar.  Even late rauchy notes.  Nice, and one of the more enjoyable and complex lagers I have ever quaffed.
Not really impressed but the idea behind the beer is impressive. Very subtle beer, nothing too crazy and very drinkable, I would recommend it but probably wouldnt drink this beer very often.

22oz bottle. Dark amber with ruby shades in the light, modest off-white head. Nose of modest malts- nutty, caramel, toffee, toast. Flavor follows with an initial burst of subtle roasty malts, followed by caramel and nuts on a carbonic bite, finishes with some molasses sweetness and ash. Medium-bodied with high carbonation. A rather rich and flavorful lager from Port that is welcomed in the ale-heavy craft market.

22oz bottle.  Ruby-brown color with a small light brown head.  Nutty, caramel, toasty malt aromas.  Ruddy, sugary malt flavors predominate.  Tinges of alefruit and an earthy hop component.  Slightly biscuity in the finish, with residual burnt caramel flavors.  Mouthfeel is a light medium.

Bottle.  Reddish  brown pour with very little head.  Aroma is mealy caramel and nuts.  Flavor is the same, salty nuts, caramel, roasted, lightly smoked and meaty, and a little cola feel in the mouth as well.

22oz bottle from By the Bottle in Vancouver, WA. Pours out the caramelly color of a coke with a very thin head. Aroma was of caramel and grass and the flavor was roasty with caramel, molasses and a little bit of smoke. Solid brew, would drink again.

Disappointing.

Pours cola colored brown with small head that disappears completely within moments.  Nose is weak to nonexistent, with a suggestion of musty caramel.  Palate has an earthy quality that is probably the rock influence, but beyond that its just a light roasty malt flavor profile.  Its watery, with not much exciting going on.

Dark and sexy amber lager, I like that.  The head was volumous, tightly woven, and khaki colored.  Nose had that grassy lagery touch with some blistered caramel, and chemical influence.  Flavors were concentrated on caramelly scorched sucrose and crystal-like notes.  A bit of pumperknickle bread notes ride by from time to time. Certainly not my style but beyond style-wide issues, not a bad beer.

Pours with a deep amber red body topped by a medium thick to thick head with a good amount of lacing.  Its sweet and malty with a nice underlying hop note and a note of dark fruit and molasses.  Medium bodied and well carbonated.
bottle, thanks to bu11zeye, cola colored pour with ring of bubbles, smokey sugar nose, flavor is same with smoke, brown sugar, nutty , cola, light overall and smooth

22oz bomber, no date--hooray the internets are back!  Clear brown--very deep in the glass--with a one finger beige head, fair retention.  Some burnt plastic I pick up on first, followed by some toasted malts and nuts.  Flavor gets a little roastier, though the nuts are still there with some added light caramel sweetness.  The finish was semi-dry and roasty with bitterness peaking around a 2.  The plastic wasnt as apparent in the flavor as it was in the aroma, thankfully.  Low prickly carbonation with a light to medium body.  Not too bad of a beer, but it gets an extra point for the brewing method.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  deep amber pour with a thin cream head.  nose is roasted malts, nuts and syrup..  very nice on the palate with a heavy roasted malt flavor and a smooth finish.

Pours dark brown with a nice off white head.  Smells of spice, earthy, some dark fruity hint, peppery.  Tastes lightly bitter and of roasted malt, caramel, more spiciness, molasses. Theres a light smokiness on the finish.  Well balanced.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Pours a deep, dark brown with red hies and beige head. Aroma os interesting, some dark fruits, toasted grains. Flavor is faintly sweet, some toasted grains, dark fruit, caramel, some spice, some bitterness. Mouth feel is medium body with high carbonation. This was an interesting beer, there were flavors I could not place though.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Pours with a small, off-white head over a clear, dark brown body. Aroma is slightly sweet, malty and floral with light fruit (very weak aroma, hard to find descriptors). Taste is ashy, tobacco, grainy, and caramel. Light bubbles and a water like mouthfeel.

Bottle. Ever since I read bout this brewing method many years ago, I have wanted to try this style of beer. I wonder what kind of rocks they used in it? Personally, I would use diabase or a nice Andesitic basalt, but thats how I roll. Body-very dark brown with red edges, medium ring of bubbles, patchy film of bubbles. Nose/taste-thin, plastic, mild noted of brown ale, earthy. The beer tastes like a thin brown ale, nothing really special here, but kudos on the process.
Slightly smokey aroma.  NIce, well balanced flavor has a tiny hint of sweetness and a slight prickliness on the tongue.  Seems like some hints of chicory as well.  Good stuff.

Name: Hot Rocks lager
Date: April 12, 2009
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting
Appearance: opaque dark amber, fine beige head, bits of drippy lace
Aroma: sweet caramelized sugar aroma
Flavor: sweet caramel malt flavor, nice chocolate, balancing earthyness, light smokeyness, touch of bitterness in the finish
